The forests, waterways and desert scrub is home to the largest reptile on the planet, the second largest bird, the largest marsupial as well as the largest monolith in the world. With this abundance of noteworthy natural history the Northern Territory can truly be called a land of extremes. This tour explores the best and wildest parts of this vast region, from Darwin to the myriad of waterways that crisscross Kakadu National Park to the vast deserts of the Red Centre and of course Uluru (Ayres Rock).

Introduction:
We are specialists in tailoring wildlife watching all over the world and we have a great range of wildlife tour in Australia. Being a country continent the hardest part is picking what to include and what not to include as it is impossible to see all of this vast and wonderful country in one trip.
When driving in the Outback it is easy to think that the desert is devoid of life, but on closer inspection Kangaroos, perenties, snakes and a wide variety of birdlife. This tour explores the centre of Australia and as well as visiting the famous Uluru (Ayres Rock) also goes in search of wildlife in the desert.
But it is not just the desert and scrub lands that are of interest on this trip, we will also be visiting the far north and the wetlands and forests of Kakadu and Litchfield National Parks. This is the realm of the Saltwater crocodile and they live here in huge numbers along side wallabies and a wealth of waterfowl.
There are so many different places to visit in the Northern Territory, this itinerary visits three of the most popular and best for wildlife sightings. Kakadu, Litchfield and Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Parks are all visited here and time spent in each location on safaris.

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including breakfasts throughout. We have our own private air conditioned 4x4 vehicles with an excellent driver for all transfers and game drives. Where possible we use two brilliant guides; first a professional zoologist (when available - zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) who will escort you on all your excursions and we also have very knowledgeable English speaking local naturalist guides who have decades of experience working and guiding through Australia.

Your naturalist escort is an expert in wildlife biology and behaviour and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. The local guides have spent years searching out the best wildlife watching locations and have an unrivalled knowledge where we are going to visit. Where needed we further employ local guides at specific locations where their intimate knowledge of individual reserves and parks is invaluable in finding our targeted species.

We also include all vehicle safaris, guided walks, park entrance fees and sightseeing entrance fees. We include more time spent in the field searching for wildlife per day than any other tour operator around; only if you request to have a rest day will we not arrange a safari into the Australian wilderness, night safaris are available in some locations (subject to the local conditions on that day). You will have to speak to your guide on arrival there and book places on these (this is not included). A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on the wildlife that you are likely to see which are available to watch throughout the tour (subject to availability of a zoologist guide - zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us).

Seasons:

August is the winter in Australia however the Northern Territory never gets truly very cold. With an average temperature of 20-30 degrees C and the lowest annual humidity it is the most pleasant time to visit. It is the dry season so there is often no rain as well. This is when we recommend this tour, however other times of year are also possible.

Why Choose this Tour:

• All of our wildlife watching holidays are guided by an experienced naturalist guides as well as local drivers and also scientists or researchers where possible, this not only gives you numerous sets of trained eyes to find the animals but also gives you the chance to understand the behaviours and habits of the wildlife you’re watching.
• Our zoologist (where available - if you wish to have a zoologist please contact us and we can check availability - not all tours include a zoologist) that escorts tours (where available) has a great wealth of knowledge.
• We can also offer further wildlife watching activities if they present themselves whilst on the trip. For example our local guides keep their ears to the ground and have many contacts and if and when a new location of animal is known and reliably seen we can head there to experience it. We do our best to include as many wildlife activities as possible in all of our itineraries.
• Depending on budget and interest we have a range of different accommodation packages to offer, from luxury top end lodges, national park safari lodges and mobile-camps which often offer unbelievable wildlife watching deep inside national parks as well as camping.
• Spend all the daylight hours searching for wildlife and visiting various natural wonders and stunning landscapes.
• All the above reasons give this, our Australian wildlife safaris a great success rate of seeing the best wildlife around here. We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides throughout Australia so that we can try and find and observe some of the rarer and more elusive species. We have great itineraries and expertise in all the Australian states and can arrange trips to find some of the rarer species such as yellow-footed rock wallabies, Tasmanian devils, greater bilbies, cassowaries among other species. Please inform us if you wish to receive more information about any of these locations and booking a safari.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

This tour visit various locations within Northern Territory, Australia. We will start and end the trip in the territorial capital of Darwin and then move east to Kakadu and Litchfield, before heading south and into the heart of the outback and to Uluru via Alice Springs.

Fitness Level:

There is some hiking here, hiking in the desert, which can be hot (even in winter), so some experience in walking in heat is recommended, but there are no particularly strenuous hikes included in this trip.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; the equipment list will vary from tour to tour and from location to location so it is best to contact us or wait until you receive the pre-departure pack after booking.

Minimum Age: 15 Years Old

dayInfo.description: Darwin - Arrival - On your arrival you will be met by your local guide/driver and he will drive you all to our accommodation in Darwin. The rest of the day and evening will be for you to relax and explore Darwin if you wish. We usually take the first day easy as the flight is very long and the heat and humidity in Darwin can take some getting used to. There is an optional excursion to the George Brown Darwin Botanical Gardens if you are interested and not too jetlagged. These gardens are a joy to walk around and if we keep a keen eye looking around we can spot some of the many birds which live around here such as blue-faced honeyeaters, rufous owls, chestnut rails, orange-footed scrub fowl, rose-crowned fruit doves and many other species which are resident here or just visiting the gardens. (No meals included today).

Adelaide River - Wildlife Watching - Today, after breakfast you will be taken to a location on the banks of the Adelaide River. This river has one of the highest concentrations of estuarine (saltwater) crocodiles in the world. These huge animals are the largest reptiles on the planet. For an hour we will have a river cruise to see some of the largest ones in the river and as well as the crocs there are hundreds of birds around here from majestic white-bellied sea eagles to whistling kites showing off their aerial prowess. (Breakfast only included).

Kakadu National Park - Wildlife Watching - After breakfast we will drive towards Kakadu National Park; the largest national park in Australia and an UNESCO World Heritage Site. There is a birding stop along the way at Fogg Dam. Here we have a chance of seeing rainbow pittas, little curlews, lemon-billed flycatchers, red-tailed black cuckoos and many other species along the boardwalks and viewing platforms. On our arrival into Kakadu you will check into the accommodation and have the rest of the day to rest and relax. (breakfast only).

Alice Springs - Travelling - Today we will have an early breakfast and head back north to Darwin where we will catch our flight to the dead centre of Australia; Alice Springs (2 hours). On arrival in Alice Springs you will be taken to your accommodation and after settling in have an afternoon visit to the Alice Springs Desert Park. This is an ideal place to see some of the rarer animals of the Australian outback. The park is a very new building and one which really makes you feel like your walking through the desolate desert. We can see thorny devils, spiny-tailed monitor lizards, zebra finchs and other desert dwellers in their natural environment and by visiting the nocturnal house we can see marsupials which are on the brink of extinction throughout most of their range. (Breakfast only).

West MacDonnell Ranges - Wildlife Watching - Today you will be driven to the West Macdonnell Ranges National Park (2 hours) and here we see the real outback. As the sun can be very hot and harsh here we will spend as little or as much time as you want here. Walking and driving around to try and spot some of the resident animals, which somehow make a living in this extreme of all places. There are species such as spinifex pigeons, black-footed rock wallabies, thorny devils and double-barred finches which can be found here. In the afternoon we will visit Simpsons Gap, Glen Helen Gorge and Ellery Creek Big Hole before returning to our accommodation in Alice Springs (Breakfast and lunch included).

Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park - This morning you will leave Alice Springs and travel further into the red centre. Our destination is the town of Yulara (5.5 hours), this is the closest town to the most famous rock in the world. Once we arrive at Yulara there is only one thing that catches the eye. Uluru, formerly called Ayres Rock, is the largest monolith in the world! After checking in we will visit Uluru for the first time as we aim to catch the incredible sunset. We will also look for some wildlife around the desert here before returning to the accommodation. (Breakfast only included.

Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park - Before dawn we will depart and get to Uluru to watch the sunrise, whilst of course looking out for wildlife in the early morning. After sunrise we will take a drive around the rock and see if we can spot some of the birds and reptiles which make the desert their home. Birds like peregrine falcons, pied butcherbirds, crimson chats, black-faced woodswallows and black-breasted buzzards are commonly seen as for reptiles they are dominated by the forth largest lizard in the world the perentie. In the late morning we will go back to the accommodation to escape the midday heat and then in the afternoon head back to Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park and then we will look out for dingoes, emus, perenties, mulgaras, woma pythons, black-footed rock wallabies and the deserts most unusual resident. Dromedary camels; we you may think that camels are not very unusual in the desert but these huge animals are native to north Africa and Arabia and are actually extinct the their native lands. Today we will also visit Kata Tjuta or the Olgas. This is a group of large sandstone rocks (similar to Uluru) form a great vista of rounded red mounds against the dead flat desert background. We will watch sunset here and head back to the accommodation. (breakfast only included).

Alice Springs - This morning you will leave Yulara and drive back again to Alice Springs (5.5 hours) after breakfast. Once we reach Alice Springs we will have the rest of the day and night to relax and enjoy the desert night and sky. (Breakfast only included)

Darwin - This morning you will be taken to the airport after breakfast. Here you will catch your return flight north to Darwin (2 hours) and once in Darwin you will check into your accommodation and then have the rest of the day to do as you please. (breakfast only included).
Home - Today you will be taken to your accommodation in time to catch your return flight home. (Breakfast only).

tourName: B&B self drive tour of Tasmania, meet the locals
placesVisited: Woolmers Estate, Launceston, National Rose Garden, Tamar Valley, Narawntapau National Park, Cradle Mountain, Dove Lake, Sarah Island, Western Wilderness, Bonnet Island, Wilderness retreats, Central Highlands, Lake St Clair, Mount Field National Park, Hobart, South West National Park, Great Tasmanian wildlife, Top Tasmania B&B's with conservation expertise
generalInfo:
Enjoy the best of Australia's wilderness island state, on this B&B self drive tour of Tasmania, meeting the locals along the way as you travel from north to south, and east to west. On this self drive holiday you will be staying in authentic farm stays and family run bed and breakfasts, wilderness cabins, homesteads and convict built cottages where you will have the chance to meet local islanders, including many who are deeply immersed in wildlife and environmental conservation in this magical island that become the life-raft for mainland Australia's long lost species over ten thousand years ago.

Your drives, from 45 minutes to no more than three and a half hours at a time, will take you through some of the most stunning landscapes in the Southern Hemisphere, with innumerable opportunities to stop and walk to dramatic tumbling waterfalls, vast, deep silent lakes, through pockets of rainforest, the tallest flowering trees in the world towering above you at over 100 metres, and surprise lookouts giving way to vistas across endless mountain ranges

Much of the accommodation is just a short drive away from Tasmania's iconic beauty spots, others are tucked away in Land for Wildlife spots, and some are so far off the tourist trail that you won't find them in any other tour operator brochure. Each will hold a wonderful surprise, with a warm welcome and a host of surprises guaranteed. Enjoy absolutely unique wildlife experiences such as inquisitive wallabies and the normally elusive platypus in your own back garden stream. Enjoy mouth watering home cooking with local produce, sometimes collected from your own back garden, and Tasmania's acclaimed wines. Stay in World Heritage listed convict sites and get an insight into Tasmania as it existed in the 1800s, when it invoked fear into the wretched souls who were transported to 'Van Diemen's Land'.

Get off the beaten track into some of Tasmania’s most stunning and bird and wildlife-rich hideaways. Stand on the Edge of the World and gaze across to South America or south to the Antarctic, with no landmass between you and there, as you breathe the cleanest recorded air in the inhabited world. Discover the very spot that launched the world’s first eco-tourism movement and changed the face of Australian politics.

Your tour will be tailored to suit your preferred duration from 7 days to 21 days or longer. A minimum of 10 to 14 days is needed for a self drive tour that includes both the east and west coasts of Tasmania. The itinerary provided below is a just a guideline. It can start in Hobart, Launceston or Devonport. Car rental is included but guests can bring their own car if they prefer to come via ferry from Melbourne, and the price will be adjusted accordingly.

dayInfo.description: You can fly into Hobart in the south, or Launceston in the north. In Hobart, perhaps allow a weekend to enjoy the famous Salamanca Markets. If you fly into into Launceston, Tasmania's second largest city in the north of the state, it is only a 45 minute flight from Melbourne. From here, collect your hire car (no hidden extras to pay!) You can stay in the city itself, and hike in Cataract Gorge and enjoy the unique Tamar Wetlands - a haven for birds and reptiles; or drive just over twenty minutes to pretty rural working Brickendon Farm and colonial Estate, which was settled in 1824 and has been in the same family of Tasmanians for seven generations. The neighbouring property, connected by a lovely walk across the land, is the glorious Woolmers Estate and National Rose Garden. Both are UNESCO World Heritage Listed and have lovely authentic accommodation. You will find the most significant, precious and well preserved convict heritage in Australia here. Stay at one of Brickendon’s charming farm or estate cottages. Enjoy the stunning countryside, take the family pig for a walk and catch your dinner in the river. The accommodation here is the closest you will find to times gone by but with modern conveniences. Continental breakfast provisions included.

Discover wineries and the 'Serengeti of Tasmania'. Drive an hour north to the head of the Tamar Estuary to Beauty Point, with stunning views across the Tamar Valley and perfectly situated to explore Tasmania’s wine route the Tamar Valley and Narawntapau National Park, full of birds and boxing kangaroos, and Archers Knob walk with views across the entire north coast of Tasmania! Your B&B's beautiful gardens run down to the Tamar River. Your hosts will spoil you rotten and give you a King's Breakfast to set you up for a day's exploration.

Head down to the beautiful Great Western Tiers, where your accommodation tonight is a hidden studio tucked between the mountains and the forest with stunning views, organic supper platters, and guided forest walks. The valley retains the landscape values of 19th Century rural Australia. Winding roads are overhung with trees, meandering creeks support native wildlife and there are no power-lines or intensive agriculture to spoil the soft lines of the valley edge. All householders living within the valley use alternative power for their domestic needs. From the southern end of the valley you can access the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area. From Adam's Peak at the top of the track on a clear day you can see far across the Central Plateau Conservation Area. The slopes of the valley are heavily forested while the valley floor has been used sporadically for farming for the last century. The old growth forests of the valley are very diverse because they contain elements of most of Tasmania's forest communities, from dry eucalypts and myrtle dominated rainforest to alpine and sub-alpine species. The now rare King Billy pine grows on the edge of the Warners Track.

The lost valley - quolls, devils and platypus. Your log cabin tonight is in a valley known to almost no one apart from those lucky enough to stumble upon it, deep in the north western wilderness. Your hosts have been stewards of this private wildlife conservation area for decades and you will almost certainly see platypus in the wild, pademelons, quolls and probably Tasmanian devils. Or stay in a magnificent glass dome on a wildlife reserve near the tiny town of Penguin complete with outdoor bath for stargazing, and the 'Devil's Den' for meals. Walk in nearby powerful Leven Canyon.

Breathe the cleanest air in the world! Today you will head to the far North West and the spot where the cleanest air in the world is regularly recorded at the CSIRO testing station. This is Stanley, a beautiful little fishing town where you will enjoy some of the freshest seafood in the world with some of the best views of your life across (and from) The Nut, the dramatic plug of volcanic rock that rises out of the Bass Strait.. Take a short drive down to the Tarkine Rainforest for a truly memorable cruise on an old restored Huon Pine Vessel down Arthur River and watch sea eagles swooping for fish. Those who long to get away from the 21st Century can continue south along the 'Road to Nowhere' - a former logging track that takes you the only accommodation in the Tarkine Rainforest on the banks of the mystical Pieman River. Don't bother checking your phone or emails here - you are truly 'off the grid'!

Cradle Mountain. An hour and a half drive brings you to the stunning glacial and alpine World Heritage landscape that is home to Cradle Mountain and Dove Lake. Stay in lovely self catering cabins with views of the mountain itself. Walk around Dove Lake, or those with a desire to get off the beaten track, start on the boardwalk that is the beginning of the world famous six day Overland Track and take the 3 hour Crater Lake Walk, passing probably not another human soul. When you return to the car, if light is just fading, stand on the boardwalk again and watch as the button grass hummocks start to move and wombat after wombat appears in the dusk. This is a great opportunity to come face to face with the Tasmanian devil at close quarters and learn from the experts at the Devils@cradle Sanctuary who will tell you all about the devastating disease that is causing its tragic demise.

Stand on the spot that started the world's first Green Party: Drive two hours through ever- changing scenery to Strahan, home to Sarah Island, the most feared of all penal settlements. This is now the gateway to Tasmania’s majestic World Heritage Listed Western Wilderness. The tiny fishing village on the edge of Macquarie Harbour, six times the size of Sydney’s, became the base camp for the massive fight to save the mighty and wild Franklin River from plans to dam it for the Hydro-electric scheme in 1982 and 1983. This was the start of the world’s first eco-tourism movement and it has remained protected and pristine ever since. Enjoy two nights at one of Tasmania's grandest manor houses, now a B&B set in lovely gardens, or a self contained apartment, both yards from the magnificent harbour. Several excursions operate from here including the Gordon River Cruise, and the original rack and pinion rainforest railway that once transported minerals from Queenstown to the harbour port of Strahan.

The Southern Central Highlands. Both Derwent Bridge and Tarraleah are fascinating stopping-off point on the long, windy and spectacularly scenic but at times challenging drive down to Hobart that crosses more eco-zones in the two hundred miles or so than anywhere else on earth. Make sure you stop at the Wall in the Wilderness at Derwent Bridge. This will, one day, be one of the world’s greatest sculptures, a 100 metre long wooden work of art crafted by one man, Greg Duncan, telling the story of the Tasmanian central highlands from aboriginal times through to the Tasmanian Tiger. Stay at a beautiful sheep farm and homestead with platypus in the lake and gourmet dinners, or a self contained cottage with floor to ceiling glass windows giving panoramas over the lake to the rolling pastures and mountains beyond. Visit the Mt Field National Park with the world's tallest flowering trees and 80 m high waterfalls, and perhaps paddle with the platypus at dusk.

An island off an island life and the world's only wild white wallabies. Head north back towards Hobart, and hop on a little 15 minute car ferry from Kettering to Bruny Island, a ravishingly beautiful national park with Australia’s highest sea cliffs, home to all twelve endemic birds and the world’s only wild white wallabies. South Bruny has lots of rustic but comfortable accommodation including delightful beachfront cottages, a heavenly Land for Wildlife farm stay, and a number of lovely little beach house style properties. Enjoy excellent food at the local pub, Hotel Bruny.

Head up Tasmania's stunning east coast, lined with olive groves and wineries with blinding views over to Maria Island - a 'must-do' day trip, self guided by foot or bike or a wonderful little cruise (also home to a magical 3 night walk for those with a little extra time to spend and the urge to dust off their walking boots). Stay tucked away from the crowds in an eco B&B where superb cooking and lovely views across the bay await, or a former convict built barracks, now a lovely boutique B&B. Take a day trip to Freycinet Peninsula and Wineglass Bay if you must but leave the tourists behind and head for a longer walk around the Hazards. Take to the water with a small, privately guided cruise to the Maria Island National Park that will show you this remarkable landscape of Tasmania's east coast including 250 million year old cliffs and caves, along with sea eagles, fur seals, albatross and dolphin.

tourName: Circular tour of Tasmania
generalInfo:
Our 8 Day Tasmania in Circle tour is our most popular offering. Designed to fit neatly into 1 week this tour is our best option for sampling Tasmania in its entirety. Covering approximately 1500km we explore many of Tassie’s premier attractions, moving fast enough to provide a fantastic overview of the island, yet slow enough to enjoy the sights! Suitable for all ages and fitness levels this is truely an amazing, small group travel experience.

Highlights:
• The stunning panoramic views from Mt Wellington Summit.
• Visit a winery in one of Tasmania’s most famous wine regions the Coal Valley.
• Fully guided tour of Australia most famous culturally historic site - Port Arthur.
• 25min Harbour Cruise of Port Arthur aboard the the spacious catamaran vessel Warana.
• Tasmania’s east coast and the incredible Bay of Fires.
• Sampling some of the best & freshest food and wine in all of Australia.
• Stroll through the lovely grounds of Cataract Gorge in Launceston.
• Fully guided tour at the unique Marakoopa show Caves, includes viewing some of the best Glow Worms in Australia.
• Majestic Cradle Mountain and its stunning highland scenery.
• Evening animal spotting adventure in Cradle Mountain including Wallabies, Pademelons and our favourite the Wombats!
• The rugged west coast - where many travellers never venture.
• The Wall in the Wilderness art Gallery in Derwent Bridge.
• Tasmania’s most photographed waterfall - the 3 tiered Russell Falls.
• Fully accredited and experienced local guides.

Inclusions:
• 7 nights accomodation
• 7 breakfasts and 6 lunches provided
• 1 x evening meal.
• All accommodations provided 3.5-4 star rated.
• All attractions, entry fee’s and National Parks passes provided.
• The only additional expenses incurred are 6 x evening meals & and any spending money.

dayInfo.description: Arrival - Arrive today and travel into Hobart city at your leisure. Your accommodation for tonight is booked and waiting at the elegant, 4-star Movenpick Hotel centrally located and walking distance to the cities restaurant and shopping areas.

Hobart to Port Arthur - Pick up from the Movenpick Hotel to begin the fully guided portion of your tour package. Explore the Hobart waterfront area before heading to the summit of Mt Wellington (1270m) boasting spectacular panoramic views in every direction. Further exploration through town sees us take in the historic Female Factory & Cascade Brewery while viewing many of Australia’s oldest convict built structures. Heading east we meander into the Coal River Valley, one of Tasmania’s premier wine regions. Naturally we will lunch at a lovely, family operated winery, sampling some of Tassie’s best wine & local produce before continuing on to the historic township of Richmond. We will see the beautiful stone arch construction of the Richmond Bridge, built by the convicts in 1823 this is Australia’s oldest bridge still in operation. Much to everyone’s delight we stop at the boutique Federation Chocolate factory just outside of Richmond for some sampling of fresh, hand made chocolates. The flavours change depending on the season and the produce available! It’s then on to the Tasman Peninsula for our first taste of the east coast. The Tasman National Park boasts towering sea cliffs and a wealth of cultural history as we venture south. A beautiful lookout point over Pirates Bay provides the ideal location for a scenic, mid-afternoon tea/coffee break. Learn about Eaglehawk Neck - the site of the infamous Dogline - as we cross onto the Tasman Peninsula. We then explore some of nature’s true wonders with short, scenic walks at Tasman’s Arch & Devils Kitchen. Continuing on we squeeze in a stop at the colourful Port Arthur Lavender Farm before overnighting right on the cusp of the Port Arthur World Heritage Historic Site.

Port Arthur to Bicheno - Our day begins with a 2.5 hour fully guided tour around the Port Arthur Historic Site. Explore many of the original buildings as we learn about the early convicts and the role they played in Tasmania’s history. Learn about Point Puer (the juvenile boys prison), the Isle of the Dead graveyard and the Port Arthur timber industry while enjoying a short, scenic harbour cruise to view the site as incoming convicts would have. Next we leave the Tasman Peninsular for our journey up the very east coast of the island. Lunch at another stunning winery overlooking the Boomer Bay area at Bangor Vineyard. At Raspins Beach we view the imposing Maria Island off the coast of Orford before stopping to see the unique convict built Spikey Bridge and the captivating coastline at Spikey Beach over tea, coffee & biscuits. Next up is Swansea – a beautiful East Coast town - and the Great Oyster Bay area. Arriving in Bicheno for our evening accomodation we will squeeze in one last feel good activity by spotting the cute little Fairy Penguins arriving ashore right in Bicheno township.

Bicheno to Launceston - Start the day at the amazing Blow Hole on the rocky coastline of Bicheno. Enjoy travelling Tasmania’s most scenic coastal road with breathtaking views of the east coast en route to one of Tasmania’s premier attractions - the Bay of Fires. At Binalong Bay we will stroll along the pure white sandy beaches and snap photos of possibly the most colourful spot on the island. Sample and enjoy the freshest possible oysters from a local oyster farm. In the afternoon we proceed towards Launceston stopping at Pyengana, the award winning cheese factory and dairy. We then twist our way through an ancient Myrtle Rainforest and cross the trail of the dragon, an old mining area centred around the town of Derby. The carved memorial trees at Legerwood are one of Australia most unique & tasteful memorial sites, this will be our tea & coffee break for today before arriving in Launceston CBD for our evenings lodgings.

Launceston to Cradle Mountain - Today we will spend the morning exploring downtown Launceston - Australia’s 3rd oldest capital city behind Sydney & Hobart. We will see the King Bridge, City Park, inside the beautiful old Heritage listed Post Office and of course take a 40 minute stroll through a jewel in the city - Cataract Gorge Reserve. Soon after we head westward into the Meander Valley which is an absolutely stunning farming and pastural area. Try local made ice-cream and honey tastings of more than 50 flavours at the renowned Melita Honey Farm in Chudleigh before learning about Tasmania’a oldest and biggest Leatherwood Honey producer R. Stephens Honey in Mole Creek. Our lunch stop today is a true gem hidden in the forest at 41o Degrees South Salmon Farm. After lunch a truely unique attraction follows with a guided tour of the Marakoopa Caves, exhibiting limestone & crystal formations millions of years old, along with a completely natural population of resident glow worms! From here we will snake our way up onto the central highlands plateau to Cradle Mountain National Park to partake in some up close Wombat & animal spotting at dusk.

Cradle Mountain to Queenstown - Start the day with a full buffet hot and cold banquet breakfast at Cradle Mountain Hotel. Inside the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park - a photographers paradise - drive to the gorgeous Dove Lake for breathtaking views of Cradle Mountain. Take a short walk to glacier rock and then on to the appropriately named Enchanted Walk to see beautiful cascades and the Pencil Pine waterfall. Visit the old “Waldheim Cottage” of pioneer Gustav Weindorfer who made Cradle Mountain world famous. En route to Strahan we pass through beautiful Lake Rosebery, old mining towns such as Day 7 – Queenstown to Hobart Zeehan and view the Southern Ocean from one of the best lookout points on the west coast - how far can you see - perhaps Argentina? This is some of the freshest air on Earth. Arriving in the historic settlement of Strahan we see the historical train station at Regatta Point, visit an old though still operational saw mill and the award winning Woodcraft Centre with beautifully designed woodworks on display. Continue on to our comfortable lodgings at the infamous west coast township of Queenstown where an evening meal will be provided by your hosts.

Queenstown to Hobart - Queenstown is an old mining town reflecting past glory and surrounded by colourful, mineral rich mountains. Start the day with panoramic views over Queenstown from the Iron Blow lookout at the top of Mt Lyell before a lovely rainforest drive right through the World Heritage Franklin-Gordon National Park. Take a stroll into possibly Tasmania’s most photogenic waterfall - Nelson Falls, the 30 minute return walk is one of the west coasts best. We then travel through picturesque valleys and mountains, pristine forests, cross wild rivers before winding our way up Mt Arrowsmith to the geographical centre of Tasmania. Button grass plains, Eucalyptus forests, majestic mountains and spectacular lakes are in every direction here. Turn at Derwent Bridge to see Lake St Clair – Australia’s deepest freshwater lake and the inception of the mighty Derwent River. Next up is lunch at one of the states premier cultural experiences - The Wall, an amazing ongoing work by artist Greg Duncan, depicting stories of Tasmanian history hand carved in Huon pine - our most famous timber. Following lunch we have a close-up look at Tasmania’s Hydro-Electric Power scheme in the township of Tarraleah, before pushing further east into the Derwent Valley. A mid afternoon coffee stop is in order at Lake Meadowbank before detouring into Mt Field National Park to visit the delightful 3 tier Russell Falls. Our final drive leg wanders along side the Derwent River bringing us back to Hobart city centre for the final night of packaged accommodation.
Departure - This concludes your hosted Tasmanian adventure with hotel check-out by 11am. We are sure you will take home lots of amazing memories & experiences.

tourName: Franklin River rafting holiday in Tasmania
placesVisited: Franklin River, Launceston, Professional river guides, Newlands Cascades, Great Ravine, Blushrock Falls, Galleon Bluff, Verandah Cliffs, Sir John Falls, Macquarie Harbour
generalInfo:
Just the names of staging posts along the Franklin River evoke the adventures which lie ahead: Nasty Notch, the Churn, the Black Forest, and Newlands Cascades. No previous experience with a paddle is needed for this small group rafting holiday in Tasmania, but it sure won’t hurt.

Led by professional guides who will bring the river and its stories to life as you go, you’ll travel as far as Sir John Falls, over tricky rapids as well as sublimely tranquil stretches of water. At night you’ll pitch up in campsites by the river, enjoying excellent food no matter how far you may be from civilization. While you eat, you can listen to the sounds of the river and the wildlife it supports, and enjoy the incredible starry skies this far from the city.

Make no mistake, you’re at the mercy of the elements out here, but no matter the conditions of the river, your in safe hands all the way, and your guides will always have a Plan B just in case. And once you reach the finish line there will be a Stormbreaker yacht waiting to carry you back in style to base in Launceston.

This awesome eight-day rafting trip is perfect for anyone with a reasonable level of fitness and a thirst for adventure. You’re out there in a real wilderness, so expect no home comforts, just the thrill of being fully immersed in nature at its most raw.

dayInfo.description: We pick you up early this morning in Launceston, from one of our two pick up locations. Our first pick up point is at 6:15am from the Grand Chancellor and our second pick up point is at 6:30am at the Penny Royal. We then drive to our put-in point at Collingwood Bridge. We aim to be there around 12:00pm and here we will inflate and load our rafts and have lunch. Before getting on the water the guides will provide a safety briefing and instruction on paddling the raft. Today we will tackle the Log Jam, Nasty Notch, Descension Gorge and float calmly through the Irenabyss and camp just on the side of the river below the gorge. We spend the evening relaxing at our idyllic camp deep in the wilderness. While your guides prepare a hearty evening meal, why not take a cup of tea down to the river to look for the wildlife that comes out at dusk. *You will need to arrive in Launceston the day before your trip, ensuring that you arrive in time to attend the 1:00pm pre-trip briefing.

Today is a long and beautiful day of rafting, with some interesting paddling and numerous campsites along the river banks. The mood of the river depends completely on how much rain has fallen recently. Keep your eye out for the red flowers of climbing heath cascading down the surrounding rock faces. Tonight we enjoy another feast prepared by your guides, then turn in for a night under the open sky.

We reach the Great Ravine today and the first major portage at the Churn. There are some challenging sections along the river prior to reaching the Churn. We pass Blushrock Falls, named for the red tinge in the rock. As we paddle look out for a view of Frenchman's Cap from the river. Your passionate guides will tell you about the Franklin’s famous history, and also intriguing lesser known tales that have come to them over their years of adventuring on this wild river. Tonight we camp at Coruscades Camp within the Great Ravine.

Today takes us to Deliverance Reach, the end of the Great Ravine, and on to Rafter's Basin. After breakfast we paddle and portage through Coruscades, Livingstone’s Cut, Thunderush, the Masterpiece and the Cauldron to the Mousehole – a narrow recess with a cat-like boulder overlooking the river. It is only a 2km paddle now from the Mousehole to Rafter’s Basin where we camp for the night by Interlude Creek. The terrain around our camp tonight is somewhat of a prelude of the forecoming Lower Franklin.

Depending on the weather today our destination is The Black Forest or Newlands Cascades. Life on the river is extremely dominated by the weather and your guides are adaptable, with a great plan B no matter what mother nature throws down at them... it's all part of the adventure! Today we paddle through Propsting Gorge and some of the Franklin's best rapids. After lunch we navigate the longest rapid on the river: Newlands Cascades. We'll also visit Rock Island Bend. At the bottom of these rapids there is a long, large rock overhang which makes a cosy place to spend the night.

Greet the morning with a hot drink in hand, watching the sun creep down the sides of the valley towards our camp. Huon Pines and Leatherwood trees drape themselves elegantly along the banks of the river. Listen and look for the birds that flit amongst their branches. The paddling today is relatively straightforward, to Blackman’s Bend through the deep temperate rainforest of the lower river that was protected by the environmental protests of the early 1980s.

Today our adventure takes us past Double Fall, Big Fall, and Galleon Bluff, which is said to look similar to the sterns of several ships jutting out into the dark water. Shortly after we float under the impressive overhang of Verandah Cliffs. Today we will visit the Lost World and acknowledge passing the Kutikina Aboriginal Cave. Our camp tonight is at Sir John Falls on the Gordon River, about 5km downstream of the junction of the Gordon and Franklin. The small wharf in front of our campsite is the perfect place from which to have a swim in the Gordon River, and to look out for white bellied sea eagles, as your guides prepare the final evening meal.

This morning you are collected by Stormbreaker yacht and cruise down the length of the river before reaching paralungatik/Macquarie Harbour. Take the chance to kick back on the deck and enjoy the views over the broad expanse of the Gordon River. In Strahan we are met by our bus, which will transfer us back to Launceston (driving time is approximately 4.5 hours). Arrival in Launceston may vary from late afternoon to late evening though usually around 5pm. Our two drop-off points in Launceston are the Grand Chancellor and the Penny Royal. We usually celebrate with a group farewell dinner this evening (own expense).

tourName: Great Ocean Road 2 day tour, Australia
generalInfo:
Come and explore the whole length of this great coastal road in a relaxed and comfortable style. The diversity of this region is truly amazing and breathtaking. Our micro groups of a maximum of 8 passengers combined with our thoughtful and refined itinerary allow you to relax and unwind while taking it all in.

Your experience of this region should not be rushed or crowded. Our small groups are cared for and guided by expert guides and we have selected great food and accommodation partners to help you get the most out of your time in this special part of the world.

By choosing 2 days to explore this region you will benefit from spreading the 600km round trip from Melbourne to see the Great Ocean Road over 2 days. You will also have time to enjoy the coastal road and townships, the rainforest and the rolling hills, and spend a night overlooking the coast and waking up to the sounds of the ocean. Dinner is enjoyed at the award winning Chris's Restaurant. This tour departs on Sundays and Wednesdays

dayInfo.description: Our journey begins its coastal ties with a short walk along the beautiful waterfront in Geelong. Get a caffeine hit at one of the cafes or just enjoy the transformed promenade and the clean coastal air. Once joining the Great Ocean Road in the surfing haven of Torquay our focus turns to Australian native wildlife as we observe Eastern Grey Kangaroos in the wild. This is one of many opportunities to see and hear about our unique and unusual animals in their native habitat. Our route then starts travelling along the very scenic, cliff-hugging section of the Great Ocean Road. While winding our way along towards Lorne we stop to view sites such as the ‘Memorial Arch’ and tell you of the intriguing story about the construction of this incredible memorial road. After lunch in Lorne, the largest of the seaside villages, we cruise along more of the spectacular road, stopping at many scenic spots including Kennett River where we can see koalas in their natural habitat and many colourful native birds. Our journey then finds us in another popular seaside town, Apollo Bay, where a walk on the beach, the marina, or an exploration of the village helps you enjoy the beauty of the region. Your accommodation tonight is at Chris’s Restaurant and Villas where you can relax in a private self-contained villa set high on a hill overlooking the Southern Ocean (based on availability). This amazing setting is a great place to relax and unwind for a couple of hours before dinner at the highly renowned restaurant. This Greek and French inspired restaurant

After breakfast, our journey starts with us travelling through the Otway ranges and onto the ‘Shipwreck Coast’. Our first stop is at Castle Cove overlooking the Aire river valley. Your guide will introduce you to the strong Aboriginal heritage of the region with many tribes living prosperously around the coastline for thousands of years. In the same area millions of years ago when Australia was part of the great southern land, Gondwana, dinosaurs were roaming the land. A unique find along the coast in 1987 uncovered important clues into the world’s pre-historic past. The 12 Apostles are Icons of Australia’s natural beauty. We arrive as the stacks are lit with the morning sun making them perfect for photos and almost crowd free. This is a bonus for taking a 2 day trip as the stacks are silhouettes in the afternoon and overcrowded. After hearing of the creation of the stacks and holding some of the limestone rock you can explore the boardwalks or brave a helicopter flight along the coastline (own expense). We then visit ‘Loch Ard Gorge’, the site of the most famous 19th century Australian shipwreck. We retell the entire story from the calm voyage, the tragic wreck, the courageous survivors and their ultimate fate. While hearing the tale you will be able to see and hold some original artefacts, photos and documents from the ‘Loch Ard’ contained in our treasure chests. Port Campbell is our lunch stop for today. The small fishing village of just 350 is set in a beautiful natural port and has some wonderful cafes and restaurants for food and views. After lunch we travel to a lesser known but highly impressive area of the Great Ocean Road west of Port Campbell. This section takes in London Bridge, Bay of Islands, Bay of Martyrs, and Boat Bay before our journey turns inland and travels through open farmland towards Melbourne arriving there around 6pm.

tourName: Great Ocean Road and Grampians 3 day tour, Australia
generalInfo:
This tour is perfectly split between beach and mountains. We spend the first day and a half on the Great Ocean Road enjoying the same route as the 2 day tour and then we travel north into the mountains. It is almost like two separate tours as both regions command your full attention. The Great Ocean Road has different scenery around every corner and is full of life and movement. The Grampians is calmer and quieter and offers some incredible viewing and walking experiences as well as being very rich in Aboriginal culture and rock art.

Our aim is to provide our small groups of a maximum of 8 passengers with compelling but relaxed itineraries matched with unique and wonderful accommodation and dining experiences. Our guides will tell tales of shipwrecks and explorers and help you in any way to have a great Australian journey. Dinners are at 2 award winning restaurants; Chris's and Royal Mail Hotel.

This tour departs on Wednesdays

dayInfo.description: Our guests on this micro group tour of just 8 people are collected from their Melbourne hotels and introduced to the wonderful journey ahead. We travel through the vast volcanic plains on route to Geelong where you have time to stroll along the beautifully transformed waterfront. We start our journey along the Great Ocean Road at Torquay, stopping at various places along the coast including Bells Beach and our scenic morning tea location. A visit to a brilliant new chocolate factory is a great place to grab a coffee or engage your inner chocoholic. Our focus then turns to Australian native wildlife as we observe Eastern Grey Kangaroos in the wild. This is one of many opportunities to see and hear about our unique and unusual animals in their native habitat. Our journey then begins travelling the very scenic, cliff-hugging section of the Great Ocean Road. While winding our way along we stop to view sites such as the ‘Memorial Arch’ and tell you of the intriguing story of this incredible road. Lorne is the largest of the seaside resorts, with its abundance of cafes and restaurants it is a perfect place for a lunch break. You may even find time to have a swim or do some shopping. After lunch we cruise along the spectacular road, stopping at many scenic spots including Kennett River where we can see koalas and many colourful native birds in the wild. Travelling through Apollo Bay we take time to explore the harbour, beach and township. We then check into your private, self-contained accommodation at Chris’s Restaurant and Villas. This is an amazing location to unwind an enjoy some time looking out to sea. We have dinner tonight at the award-winning restaurant with breathtaking views of the ocean and enjoy a modern Greek Australian menu that utilises great local produce.

Our journey ventures into the Great Otway National Park where we take you on a guided walk through a cool temperate rainforest gully to see the world’s tallest flowering plants and prehistoric trees. Our first stop on the shipwreck coast is at Castle Cove overlooking the Aire river valley. Your guide will introduce you to the strong Aboriginal heritage of the region and the important fossil discoveries of dinosaurs dating back to the cretaceous period. The 12 Apostles are Icons of Australia’s natural beauty. We arrive as the stacks are lit with the morning sun making them perfect for photos and crowd free. This is a bonus for taking a 2-day trip as the stacks are silhouettes in the afternoon and overcrowded. After hearing of the creation of the stacks and holding some of the limestone rock you can explore the boardwalks or brave a helicopter flight along the coastline (own expense). We then visit ‘Loch Ard Gorge’, the site of the most famous 19th century Australian shipwreck. We retell the entire story from the calm voyage, the tragic wreck, the courageous survivors and their fate. While hearing the tale you will be able to see and hold some original artifacts, photos and documents from the ‘Loch Ard’ contained in our treasure chests. Port Campbell is our lunch stop for today. The small fishing village of just 350 is set in a beautiful natural port and has some wonderful cafes and restaurants for food and views. After lunch we travel to a lesser known but highly impressive area of the Coastline west of Port Campbell. This section includes the limestone formations of London Bridge, Bay of Islands, Bay of Martyrs and Boat Bay and is seen only be a small percentage of the people travelling the Great Ocean Road. Our journey then continues through to Warrnambool and Port Fairy with a visit to Tower Hill Game Reserve for the chance to see Koalas, Kangaroos and Emus living wild within this extinct volcanic crater. We then leave the coast and drive north to your accommodation in Dunkeld at the southern end of the Grampians National Park. The Royal Mail hotel is a renowned hotel for both its setting, looking out at the mountains, but also its culinary excellence, having been awarded many mighty accolades over the times. Your experience here includes the five-course degustation menu in ‘Wickens’. This dining experience is something that has people from all over Australia travelling for.

Our third day starts at the Southern end of Gariwerd, the Aboriginal name for the Grampians. After enjoying breakfast at the hotel we start an incredibly scenic drive North between the Serra and Mt William Ranges towards Hall’s Gap while the sun is streaming in from the east lighting up the rocky cliff faces of the ranges. The creation of these ranges dates back around 420 million years ago and has at one stage had the Southern Ocean lapping up against it. These sandstone mountain ranges are sedimentary deposits that have since faulted and lifted. This upheaval now allows us to discover an incredibly rare and stunning landscape. An hour into our journey we arrive in Halls Gap in the heart of the Grampians NP. This township’s Parks Victoria information centre and ‘Brambuk’ Aboriginal cultural centre help us learn about the region, including a couple of short videos in the dreaming theatre that reveals both the the natural history and the Aboriginal creation story. Our day includes a few short walks at Baroka Lookout, Reid’s Lookout and McKenzie Falls as well as the rock art site ‘Bunjil’s Shelter’. Our journey back to Melbourne takes us by the gold mining township of Ballarat, once one of the richest towns in the world and the reason for Melbourne’s early prosperity. The end of our 3-day tour concludes back in Melbourne around 6pm.

tourName: Holiday to Tasmania for New Zealanders
generalInfo:
Tasmania - Australia's only island state - is an easy journey from New Zealand. At 40 degrees South, it lies just an hour or so from Melbourne and Sydney, yet in the relatively short time it takes to get there, you might as well have landed in another world.

Excitement builds as your plane begins its descent over seemingly endless mountain ranges, stretching as far as the eye can see, all deeply forested and carved up by wild rivers and deep, dark lakes and pockets of rich pastures. As your plane banks you will see that the island is fringed by startling white sand beaches lapped by brilliant turquoise seas.

Any sign of civilisation is all but invisible until you land at Hobart Airport.

Even then, you will be immediately struck by island's calm, tranquil lifestyle. Locals consider themselves first and foremost to be Tasmanian, and only then Australian. They are justly proud of their peaceful existence, as they also are of their rich convict heritage.

What awaits you now is a melting pot of history and culture, an abundance of wildlife that might have hopped or waddled straight from the pages of a fairy tale, and day after day of adventure.

This Land, among the most diverse and fertile in the world, provides a mouth-watering array of produce, wines and whiskies, all of which is clearly evident within minutes of landing.

Tasmania has everything you could possibly ask for in a dream holiday, all wrapped up in an island the size of Sri Lanka.

This is quite possibly the land that time forgot. And yet ....

Within this land where Nature is King, you will also find one of the most vibrant, cosmopolitan small cities on the planet. The harbour city of Hobart, despite its serene location on the River Derwent with Mount Wellington as its backdrop, is a buzzing hotchpotch of history, art, culture, food, wine and people.

On this magical Tasmanian odyssey you will begin your self-drive holiday from Hobart on a day to suit you, and explore for as little or as long as you wish.

While most visitors are keen to see the classic icons of Tasmania - Wineglass Bay and Cradle Mountain - the real joy of this holiday lies in our local knowledge and ability to take you away from the tourists, to new horizons, down untrodden paths and the road less travelled to hidden gems that not even the best travelled Aussies can tell you about.

Each journey we create is designed to showcase the best of Tassie. ‘Meet the locals’ in charming B&Bs. Dine on delicious home cooking. Hide away in wilderness cottages. Relax in restored homesteads from a bygone era.

The style and pace of our holidays are tailored to suit any age and ability, from the young and active to the mature and mellow, even those with limited mobility. We promise you the experience of a lifetime.

We have been making dreams come true in Tassie for over 20 years. Put your dreams in the hands of Tasmanian travel experts. No one knows Tassie like we do. Our passion is to share it with you.

dayInfo.description: Your journey begins as your plane starts its descent into Hobart. You should catch your first glimpse of endless arcs of the east coast’s white sand beaches washed by an impossibly turquoise Tasman Sea before the plane banks over densely forested mountain ranges stretching as the eye can see, carved up by wild rivers and liberally peppered with inky lakes. Coming into land, you will barely have time to pinch yourself before you arrive at one of the prettiest and most vibrant cities in Australia. This is the maritime state capital, Hobart, perched insouciantly between The Mountain and the Great Southern Ocean. This is also the gateway to arguably the most beautiful and diverse island paradise in the world. And this is where your Tasmanian odyssey begins. Within half an hour you can be standing on the historic sandstone Salamanca Place where you can enjoy the best of all worlds: the pretty village of Battery Point, the year round buzz of Salamanca’s restaurants, bars and galleries, and the arresting beauty of one of the world’s most beautiful harbours with Mt Wellington as its backdrop.

If your stay in Hobart falls over a weekend you can enjoy the bustle of Tasmania’s longest running attraction – the Salamanca markets, where locals gather to chat, laugh and entertain each other with an ambience akin to a village fete. Spend the afternoon at MONA – the world famous Museum of Old and New Art, one of the world’s most extraordinary private museums, built within the Triassic sandstone cliffs of the River Derwent. Take the ferry up the river and book seats in the Posh Pit – you won’t be disappointed!

This morning you will leave Hobart and start your westward ascent. Your journey up the scenic and lush Derwent Valley will take you to one of Tasmania’s oldest and best loved national parks, Mt Field, where easy short walks will reveal 80 metre high Russell Falls and the tallest flowering trees in the world – legendary giants of the forest. Stay in a riverside cabin at the very entrance to the National Park, bidding farewell to all but four legged visitors, or a restored homestead surrounded by the rolling hills and lakes of the southern Central Highlands.

Head down to the Far South West, Lake Pedder, birthplace of the world’s first Green Party and the start of the eco-tourism movement as we know it; or continue up the magnificent Lyell Highway, the road to the wild west coast, to one of Tasmania’s most remarkable art installations, the Wall in the Wilderness. This modern-day one-man work of art is a 100 metre wooden sculpture telling the story of the Central Highlands set among the jaw dropping landscapes of the Wild Rivers National Park.

Your onward drive will take you through increasingly wild and awe-inspiring landscapes as you head towards the wild West Coast of Tasmania, via Australia’s deepest freshwater lake, Lake St Clair. This is the southernmost point of one of Australia's most famous overland treks. You can enjoy a stroll through the landscape spotting platypus and wombats, or take advantage of a guided walk with a local expert.

Today you will continue your climb through the dramatic landscapes and across the dramatic ‘moonscape’ of Queenstown. No fewer than ninety bends later, you will reach the tiny town of Strahan. This little outpost sits on the edge of Macquarie Harbour, an astonishing piece of water which is several times larger than Sydney Harbour and has no landmass between it and South America. Soak up the spine-chilling story of this remote outpost that witnessed the torture of men through horrific penal labour, only to see saw men and women stop environmental destruction in its tracks a century later. Take the West Coast Wilderness Railway under steam through virgin rainforest – a living piece of history that will bring the stories of piners and miners alive as your carriage negotiates some of the steepest gradients of any railway in the world under the Swiss designed rack and pinion system.

The drive from Strahan north will take you along the gravel road known as the Road to Nowhere and across the Pieman River on the Fatman Barge, a single vehicle ferry. You will spend the tonight at a wilderness retreat, a former mining village, deep in the heart of one of the last major stretches of temperate rainforest left on the planet.

Boarding a little restored Huon Pine vessel, you will voyage deep into the mysterious and bitterly fought over Tarkine Rainforest, which makes up 7% of Tasmania’s landmass. As you cruise down the majestic waters of this wild river, you will marvel at the shimmering reflections and walk among the most ancient trees in the world with inquisitive endemic wildlife and birds for company.

Today you will venture north, continuing on the Road to Nowhere through virgin rainforest and high over the wilderness. This is known as the Edge of the World, and for all the world it feels like it. The Roaring Forties winds sweep in from Patagonia, bring crashing waves to this region which is one of the most accessible wildernesses in the world. Breathe deeply, for you are now on the spot which consistently records the cleanest air in the inhabited world! Stanley, a perfect little gem of a town, sits peacefully at the base of a dramatic ‘Nut’ of volcanic rock at the end of a peninsula in the Bass Strait, bursting with history of early settlers and the contentment of generations of families for whom this remote corner of the world has been home. Nowhere is the warmth and friendliness of islanders, the power of nature, and the cheeky curiosity of the wildlife more evident. Tasmanian Pademelons vie for your attention, wallabies hop down the street at dusk, and comical Little Penguins brazenly strut their stuff right in front of your eyes in all their wild glory as they return from a day’s fishing in the mighty ocean.

Today you will leave the Far North West corner - but your adventure is far from over! You will continue your odyssey into yet another world as you venture into ancient devil country. Stay on a private Land for Wildlife retreat in a beautiful lost valley where endangered Tasmanian devils and quolls, found nowhere but on this extraordinary island, roam freely, almost undisturbed by man. During your stay in a simple but spacious log cabin you will take a guided walk at dusk to spot the elusive Duck-billed Platypus before settling down in front of your log fire with a delicious home-cooked dinner, and prepare for Tasmania’s largest carnivorous marsupial to arrive on your porch – the rare and beleaguered Tasmanian devil, more often than not joined by its equally elusive cousin, the Quoll.

Today you will be able to explore one of Australia's most breath-taking canyons, arguably the most spectacular bushwalking spot in Tasmania with a fraction of those who flock to Cradle Mountain (which is an easy day trip away for those who wish to see it). Choose from one of the easy walks to two of the most dramatic lookout points in the island on canopies which are cantilevered out high over the crashing river and forests below, or one of the many more challenging walks for those with a thirst for adventure. Visit beautiful private gardens, run by a dedicated family of ladies whose green fingered prowess has attracted film crews from all over the country to this most unlikely of locations.

Leaving the enigmatic Central Highlands of Tasmania, you will meander your way to a little known region – the Great Western Tiers. On the way, stop at more magnificent gardens where several platypus can be seen on a daily basis; perhaps enjoy a guided tour at one of Tasmania’s top wildlife sanctuaries or call in at some of the many local makers – cheese, honey, chocolate, salmon and cool climate wines. Spend tonight in a three room eco lodge, where the owners is as famed for his gourmet cooking as for his knowledge of the forests, which he will share on a never to be forgotten guided walk through the forest before he dons his chef’s whites for an equally memorable dinner of local produce. Although just an hour from Launceston and Devonport, you are unlikely to see another soul during your stay here.

Head towards Launceston, and stroll around ‘Cataract Gorge’, the ‘Wilderness in the Heart of the City’, taking the world’s longest chairlift across the impressive natural gorge. Culture vultures can visit two of Tasmania’s World Heritage Listed convict sites where the most precious and perfectly preserved convict history in Australia is set among acres of fabulous gardens including the National Rose Garden. You can actually stay in one of the original convict built cottages on the World Heritage Site, or you can head north to the aptly named Beauty Point. Despite its name and location, Beauty Point attracts surprisingly few visitors. You will love its delightful arty, local vibe – added to which you are within a short drive of the Narawntapu National Park and a beautiful swimming beach. Stay in one of the island’s most highly rated B&Bs, a true hidden gem which epitomises Tasmanian hospitality at its best, set in carefully tended cottage gardens which run down to the Tamar River.

Today you can indulge in a private winery tour taking in the best of the famous Tamar Valley wine route, or spend the day exploring local attractions including Platypus House, home to platypus and echidna; Beaconsfield Gold Mine and Seahorse World. Those on a slower pace will love the chance to simply relax and enjoy the B&B’s riverfront gardens and BBQ gazebo.

Leaving the north of the island, now it’s time to explore Tasmania’s jaw-dropping scenic east coast with its sugar-white beaches lined with vivid orange granite rocks lapped by turquoise seas, wineries, cellar doors and olive groves. Make the easy and peaceful drive through the north east wilderness to the east coast town of St Helens, gateway to the 50 km stretch of beaches known as the Bay of Fires. You can stay in St Helens itself, but those wishing to further connect with nature can enjoy a spot of glamping in the forest, just minutes from the sea although like all things Tasmanian, creature comforts are always to hand with cashmere hot water bottles and gourmet cooking.

Today you can explore the 50 km stretch of beaches by foot, by car or on a serene guided kayak trip along the secret waterways of the north east. The kayaks are ultra-stable, built for photography and fishing, so even complete novices will feel safe and secure on the calm waters.

You are now embarking on Tasmania’s Great Eastern Drive. There are several choices to make, depending on your mobility, interests and most importantly, how many people you wish to see on your travels! Wineglass Bay on the Freycinet Peninsula is one of Tasmania’s most photographed spots and an unmissable highlight for many, but if your idea of heaven is mile upon mile of untrodden wild beaches and walking trails, swimming in secret water holes and an island known as the ‘wombat capital of the world’, our recommendation is to discover the hidden delights north of the iconic Freycinet Peninsula, or equally the historic southern stretch with spellbinding views spanning the Hazards Mountain Range down to the Maria Island National Park.

Take to the seas for a small group guided boat trip into the Tasman Sea and along this glorious coastline spotting marine life such as Albatross, Australian fur seals, dolphin and possibly whales. Depending on your preferred trip, enjoy lunch at anchor in one of the world’s most photographed bays, or step ashore a ‘Noah’s Ark’ island national park, and walk around another World Heritage Convict Site, spotting wombats, kangaroos, wallabies and possibly devils

Today you will continue your drive south, across the narrow strip of land known as Eaglehawk Neck across which wild dogs were once chained to prevent the escape of convicts from one of the most feared places on the planet - Port Arthur. Stay tonight in a cabin overlooking the beautiful waters of Ladies Bay, and embark on the eerie Ghost Tour of one of the most haunted places on earth.

Today you are free to explore the World Heritage listed Port Arthur Historic Site at your leisure. Elsewhere on the Tasman Peninsula, you will find some of the most remarkable coastal walking in Australia.
Make the easy 90 minute drive to Hobart Airport for your departure flight and say farewell to Tassie.

tourName: Kakadu and Arnhem Land tours, Australia
generalInfo:
This ten day itinerary in the 'Top End' of Australia includes 3 nights in Darwin, 4 days of self-drive in the spectacular Kakadu National Park and 3 nights in the ancient and remote Arnhem Land.

The itinerary includes two small group tours in the national park, including a wonderful day-trip to the impressive Twin and Jim Jim falls, as well as a Yellow Waters cruise which takes in a multitude of bird and animal life for which the Kakadu National Park is famous. You will also spend 3 nights in the Arnhem Land, a special place of aboriginal significance, where you will spend your time touring this stunning landscape, marveling at ancient rock art and unique wildlife.

Leisure time is also included on this itinerary to explore the Kakadu's stunning escarpments, gorges, billabongs and waterfalls.

Price includes:

- Pre and post accommodation in Darwin
- Car hire for 7 days
- Three night's accommodation and touring in the Arnhem Land
- Two nights accommodation in Jabiru
- Two nights accommodation in Cooinda
- Yellow Water Cruise
- Full day tour of the Kakadu National Park
- Royalties and permits to enter Aboriginal lands.

The best time to go is the dry season from April to November. This allows for access to areas of Kakadu and Arnhem Land that are usually flooded in the wet. The weather is a lot nicer, far less humid and with hardly any rain.

dayInfo.description: Stay one night tonight in the historic town of Darwin. The day is at leisure to explore the marina region that has a number of fantastic restaurants.
Today is at leisure to explore Litchfield National Park or visit one of the amazing museums in the area.

After breakfast collect your hire car and drive to Jabiru in the Kakadu National Park. You may wish to stop off at the Adelaide River to see the jumping crocodiles and later perhaps drive north of Jabiru to visit the Aboriginal rock art site at Ubirr. On arrival in Jabiru, drop off your car hire and board your scenic flight to Davidsons lodge.

Today and tomorrow are days to explore the Arnhemland with your Davidson's tour guide. Full of rich aboriginal history, this is the perfect way to engage with the local communities and wildlife in a safe and responsible way.
A further day of touring at Davidsons today.
Today you will take a scenic flight back to the Kakadu National Park where you will pick up your car and head to your lodge for the next couple of nights.

You will be collected by your driver guide this morning for a full day cultural tour of the Kakadu National Park. Today you'll see local Aboriginal artists creating traditional works of art, marvel at pieces of ancient rock art and visit the famous and powerful Jim Jim and Twin Falls.
Spend the day exploring more of Kakadu National Park. Head down to the Cooinda region, where you will stay for a further two nights.

You will be picked up for your Yellow Waters Cruise this morning to see stunning bird life and crocodiles that frequent the area. Spend the rest of the day visiting rock art and rock pool sites under the escarpment.
Take your time today heading back to the city of Darwin, where you will stay for one further night, before continuing your onward travels.

tourName: Melbourne to Adelaide 3 day tour, Australia
generalInfo:
This tour with a maximum of 8 passengers takes in the breathtaking scenery of the Great Ocean Road, one of Australia’s best wine regions and vast farmland on route to Adelaide. If you are travelling to both cities and seeing the Great Ocean Road why go back to Melbourne and waste time flying over to Adelaide. This journey will get you in there only hours later and you will have seen another part of Australia.

The two first days are spent travelling the Great Ocean Road and beyond in a relaxed pace in the same fashion as the 2 day tour. On the third day we visit the World Heritage listed Naracoorte Caves National Park and have lunch a beautiful winery.

Let us do the driving and you can enjoy the company of our small groups and the many great experiences we have put together for your enjoyment along the way.

This tour departs Sunday

dayInfo.description: Our guests on this small group tour are picked up from their city hotel or Federation Square and we quickly depart Melbourne via the West Gate Bridge. We travel through the vast volcanic plains on route to Geelong where you have time to stroll along the beautifully transformed waterfront. Our first stop along the coast is at Bells Beach, a famous surfing beach and a great place to enjoy morning tea. Our focus then turns to Australian native wildlife as we observe Eastern Grey Kangaroos in the wild. This is one of many opportunities to see and hear about our unique and unusual animals in their native habitat. Our journey then begins travelling the very scenic, cliff-hugging section of the Great Ocean Road. While winding our way along we stop to view the ‘Arch’ and tell you of the intriguing story of this incredible memorial road. Lorne is the largest of the seaside resorts and is a perfect place for a lunch break. You may even find time to have a swim or do some shopping. After lunch we cruise along the spectacular road, stopping at many scenic spots including Kennett River where we can see koalas and many colourful native birds in the wild. Travelling through Apollo Bay we go into the Great Otway National Park. We take you on a 1km guided walk through a cool temperate rainforest gully to see the world’s tallest flowering plants, prehistoric trees and ferns and unique features such as ‘Yabbie Chimneys’. We visit Apollo Bay before checking in to your private self contained villa is set high on a hill overlooking the Southern Ocean. This amazing setting is a great place to relax and unwind for a couple of hours. After freshening up we have dinner next door at Chris's Restaurant. This award winning restaurant is certainly one of the best in the region where the great food is only matched by the amazing views.

After breakfast, our journey starts with us travelling through the Otway ranges and onto the ‘Shipwreck Coast’. Our first stop is at Castle Cove overlooking the Aire river valley. Your guide will introduce you to the strong Aboriginal heritage of the region with many tribes living prosperously around the coastline for thousands of years. In the same area millions of years ago when Australia was part of the great southern land, Gondwana, dinosaurs were roaming the land. A unique find along the coast in 1987 uncovered important clues into the world’s pre-historic past. The 12 Apostles are Icons of Australia’s natural beauty. We arrive as the stacks are lit with the morning sun making them perfect for photos and more crowd free. This is a bonus for taking a 2 day trip as the stacks are silhouettes in the afternoon and overcrowded. After hearing of the creation of the stacks and holding some of the limestone rock you can explore the boardwalks or brave a helicopter flight along the coastline (own expense). We then visit ‘Loch Ard Gorge’, the site of the most famous 19th century Australian shipwreck. We retell the entire story from the calm voyage, the tragic wreck, the courageous survivors and their ultimate fate. While hearing the tale you will be able to see and hold some original artefacts, photos and documents from the ‘Loch Ard’ contained in our treasure chests. Port Campbell is our lunch stop for today. The small fishing village of just 350 is set in a beautiful natural port and has some wonderful cafes and restaurants for food and views. After lunch we travel to a lesser known but highly impressive area of the Great Ocean Road west of Port Campbell. This section takes in London Bridge, Bay of Islands, Bay of Martyrs, and Boat Bay. Our journey then continues through Warrnambool and onto Tower Hill Game Reserve where we have the chance to see emus and other native animals. Our journey then continues through picturesque Port Fairy towards Mount Gambier. Here we look at the incredible colour of a volcanic crater lake before we check into our luxurious overnight accommodation at ‘The Barn’ in Mount Gambier and indulge in the fine food of the region in their award winning restaurant. Dinner and breakfast are both included at ‘The Barn’.

Our third day starts with a visit to the Naracoorte Caves National Park for a cave tour with a local guide. These limestone caves have an abundance of Stalagmites and Stalactites and are World Heritage Listed Area due to the fossils of the ‘Mega Fauna’ found buried in the Caves. We then continue our journey through another prominent South Australian wine region of Padthaway as we head north through to Keith. We stop here for lunch before joining the highway, travelling through grain and stock land towards Adelaide. This is a vast drought affected area of Australia and is an incredible contrast to the lush forests and coastal pastures we have been travelling in. On our approach to city we visit the very popular tourist village of Hahndorf and Mount Lofty summit for impressive, birds-eye views of Adelaide and surrounds. We arrive in the city at around 6pm.

tourName: Melbourne to Adelaide private 3 day tour
generalInfo:
As we all start to explore again, we have the perfect way to go! Private groups, relaxed pace that use boutique accommodation and restaurant meals but avoids the crowd. This is the way they have always done it... who knew they were in training.

We have over 20 years of providing Private and micro-group touring of the Great Ocean Road and beyond.

Travelling in three relaxing days, this journey gives you the time to fully immerse in the diverse splendour of this region. In a private group explore many coastal townships, spectacular sites, interesting stories, national parks and native wildlife.

We have sourced unique and stunning accommodation, high above the Great Ocean Road looking over the Southern Ocean and in Mount Gambier.

Their many stories of the region are enhanced by revealing original artefacts from the Loch Ard shipwreck and written material contained in several treasure chests. This unique interpretive theme gives guests a rare insight into the region.

tourName: Private Great Ocean Road and Grampians tour
generalInfo:
As we all start to explore again, we have the perfect way to go! Private groups, relaxed pace that use boutique accommodation and restaurant meals but avoids the crowd. This is the way they have always done it... who knew they were in training.

We have over 20 years of providing Private and micro-group touring of the Great Ocean Road and beyond.

This tour is perfectly split between beach and mountains. We spend the first day and a half on the Great Ocean Road enjoying the same route as the 2 day tour and then we travel north into the mountains. It is almost like two separate tours as both regions command your full attention. The Great Ocean Road has different scenery around every corner and is full of life and movement. The Grampians is calmer and quieter and offers some incredible viewing and walking experiences as well as being very rich in Aboriginal culture and rock art.

Our aim is to provide our private tours with compelling but relaxed itineraries matched with unique and wonderful accommodation and dining experiences. Our guides will tell tales of shipwrecks and explorers and help you in any way to have a great Australian journey. Dinners are at 2 award winning restaurants; Chris's and Royal Mail Hotel.

dayInfo.description: Our guests on this micro group tour of just 8 people are collected from their Melbourne hotels and introduced to the wonderful journey ahead. We travel through the vast volcanic plains on route to Geelong where you have time to stroll along the beautifully transformed waterfront.
