Home - Today you will be taken to the airport in time to catch your return flight home.

tourName: Tasmania coastal cruise
placesVisited: Hobart, Bathurst Harbour, Woodbridge, Huon, Recherche Bay, Port Davey, Bruny Island, Freycinet National Park, Wineglass Bay, Maria Island, Tasman National Park, Port Arthur, Optional activities include: kayaking, guided hikes
generalInfo:
Just because you’re on a cruise, doesn’t mean you can’t be active. Get out and bushwalk in Tasmania’s national parks with a park ranger on this eight day expedition along the coast. This far south you get really long days; get out and make the most of the daylight.

Think of this trip as an expedition cruise, where there are plenty of opportunities to walk and explore Tasmania’s well-protected wild places, including the start of the South Coast Track. Travelling by small ship means you can reach the UNESCO-protected Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area – a privilege normally only afforded by those with a light aircraft – or willing to hike for a week.

You’ll visit Bruny Island with its fairy penguins and its white quartz sand peninsulas. You’ll be able to reach Maria Island, where bird species flourish and there are no cars, and you’ll rise early to walk to a lookout over Wineglass Bay in Freycinet National Park, one of the most beautiful beaches in the world. Thanks to Tasmania’s cool-climate wines, it won’t be the only wineglass you’ll see on the trip, and your small ship provides local specialities for you to eat, too, from Bruny Island oysters to sheep cheese.

Highlights
• Spend two full days exploring Port Davey and Bathurst Harbour, with kayaking, bird-watching, and hiking revealing the secrets of this stunning wilderness
• Explore the beautiful Freycinet National Park: stroll the sweeping white sand of Wineglass Bay and hike to the lookout for a spectacular view
• Visit the Noah’s Ark of Tasmania, Maria Island, and spot wombat, wallabies, endemic birds, and other wildlife
• Enjoy a behind-the-scenes tour at World Heritage-listed Port Arthur to gain a deep insight into the convict history
• From the sea, have a breath-taking view of the 300 metre high dolerite columns of the Tasman Peninsula, the highest sea cliffs in the southern hemisphere
• Taste Tasmania’s remarkable fresh produce, cool-climate wines, and artisanal spirits throughout your expedition and at special wine-tastings and events

dayInfo.description: DEPART HOBART Arrive at your advised check-in location for boarding at 4:00pm, with time to settle into your stateroom before our 5:00pm departure. Take the time to become acquainted with all the facilities onboard Coral Discoverer before meeting your fellow travellers, the Captain and crew for the Captain’s Welcome Drinks.

BRUNY ISLAND From Adventure Bay on the east coast of Bruny Island, we embark on an exhilarating 3 hour tour with award-winning local operator Pennicotts Wilderness Journeys to the rugged southern coastline of South Bruny Island. Enter deep sea caves and pass through the narrow gap between the coast and ‘The Monument’ and see seals, dolphins and sea birds at close range. Later we walk along the dramatic coastal cliffs of Fluted Cape and hope to see Bennett’s Wallabies which are endemic to Bruny Island. Learn about how southern right whales were almost hunted to extinction and Adventure Bay housed four whaling stations before the industry’s decline in the mid-1840s. The ruins can be seen on a walk to Grassy Point.

MARIA ISLAND Maria Island can be referred to as a Noah’s Ark for native Tasmanian species. The Maria Island National Park provides an ideal sanctuary, and is one of the best places in Australia to observe endemic birdlife as well as wombats, Cape Barren geese, Forester Kangaroos, Bennett’s Wallabies, and pademelons. Stroll amongst the ruins and beautifully restored buildings of the Darlington convict settlement and take a walk to the striking formations of the Painted Cliffs, where rich iron deposits have stained the sandstone cliffs with coloured streaks of red, purple and orange. With ample time at Maria Island, we also have the opportunity to do the Fossil Cliffs walk and the Reservoir circuit.

FREYCINET NATIONAL PARK The Freycinet Peninsula is a dramatic headland dominated by a pink-hued granite mountain range called the Hazards. Blessed with picturesque sweeping bays with white sand beaches like famed Wineglass Bay, much of the peninsula is designated as Freycinet National Park. Take a guided hike along the Isthmus Track to Wineglass Bay, or continue on to the look out to be rewarded with magnificent views of the azure waters of this iconic beach. Later land at Schouten Island with time for a beach stroll on this secluded island.

PORT DAVEY & BATHURST HARBOUR On the edge of the world in southwest Tasmania, the landscape here is about as wild as it gets. Raw, craggy-peaked mountains and drowned river valleys. Wild rivers and rivulets carved by an eternity. Where tannin-rich freshwater sits atop saltwater, tinting the ocean the colour of tea. With no road access, the logical way to explore this wilderness is by small expedition ship. Sheltered from Roaring Forties winds that buffet this coast is the protected haven of Port Davey and Bathurst Harbour. A marine reserve and part of the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area, we spend two whole days (weather permitting) enjoying this rare opportunity to hike, kayak and take in this pristine natural environment. We explore by Xplorer tender vessels and learn about intrepid European explorers and Indigenous Australians, who once walked this land and keep a lookout for the rare and endangered Orange Bellied Parrot amongst other wildlife. *Access to Port Davey and Bathurst Harbour is subject to annual permits being granted by Tasmania Parks and Wildlife.

HUON VALLEY The Huon Valley was one the hub of Tasmania’s apple growing industry, and the reason the state is nicknamed ‘The Apple Isle’. These days this region is known for its burgeoning food and wine scene, as well as its variety of natural attractions. The picturesque Huon River winds gently through this valley, its banks lined with charming little towns, orchards and boutique wineries, before emptying out into the D’entrecasteaux channel. The southern end of this valley is bordered by the heritage listed Southwest National Park. Spend time in this picturesque valley exploring both its natural and epicurean offerings. Meet local producers, enjoy coastal walks and delight in all this region has to offer.

PORT ARTHUR HISTORIC SITE One of Australia’s most significant historic places, the UNESCO World Heritage-listed Port Arthur ruins stand sentinel on the Tasman Peninsula south of the narrow isthmus of Eaglehawk Neck. For more than 40 years the Port Arthur penal colony housed British and Australian convicts sentenced to hard labour before its heavy iron doors clanked shut for the last time in 1877. Today, the Historic Site has over 30 buildings, ruins and restored period homes set in 100 acres of landscaped grounds. In the company of Port Arthur’s knowledgeable guides, join a walking tour of this site.

TASMAN PENINSULA The Tasman Peninsula is known for its fascinating geological formations like the Tessellated Pavement, Tasman Arch, and the soaring 300 metre high dolerite sea cliffs of Cape Raoul, Cape Pillar and Cape Hauy – the tallest in the southern hemisphere. Watch fur seals hauling out on the rocks, as well as playful dolphins feeding and magnificent albatross soaring amongst the updrafts created by the sea cliffs. We will visit Fortescue Bay, hike sections of the coastal Tasman Trail, take a scenic Xplorer cruise of the rugged coastline and kayak in Canoe Bay.

DAY 11: ARRIVE HOBART Our Tasmania adventure concludes in Hobart this morning as we bid farewell to new-found friends, the Master and crew, disembarking at 8:00am. A complimentary transfer is provided to CBD hotels, or the airport is included.

tourName: Tasmania East Coast tour from Hobart
generalInfo:
Our 5 Day Eastern Tassie Coastline Tour offers a fantastic short getaway to Tasmania’s east coast. This tour is a great option for those who only have limited travel time available but wish to see some of our most scenic attractions. It’s also a great option for those that wish to start in Hobart and finish in Launceston. Covering approximately 800km we explore several of Tasmania’s premier east coast attractions, moving fast enough to fit in many great experiences, yet slow enough to enjoy the sights! This tour concludes on Thursday morning in Launceston CBD with hotel check-out by 11am. Suitable for all ages and fitness levels this is an unforgettable, small group travel experience.

Highlights:
• The stunning panoramic views from Mt Wellington Summit.
• Visit a winery in one of Tasmania’s most famous wine regions the Coal Valley.
• Fully guided tour of Australia most famous culturally historic site - Port Arthur.
• 25min Harbour Cruise of Port Arthur aboard the the spacious catamaran vessel Warana.
• Tasmania’s east coast and the incredible Bay of Fires.
• Visit the award winning Nature World for an interactive experience with Tasmania’s native animals including the Tasmanian Devil.
• Sampling some of the best & freshest food and wine in all of Australia.
• Fully accredited and experienced local guides.

Inclusions:
• 4 nights accomodation.
• 4 x breakfasts and 3 x lunches provided.
• Direct hotel pick-up and drop-off.
• All accommodations provided 3.5-4 star rated.
• All attractions, entry fee’s and National Parks passes provided.
• The only additional expenses incurred are 4 x evening meals & and any spending money.

dayInfo.description: Arrival in Hobart: Arrive today and travel into Hobart city at your leisure. Your accommodation for tonight is booked and waiting at the elegant, 4-star Movenpick Hotel centrally located and walking distance to the cities restaurant and shopping areas.

Hobart - Port Arthur: Pick up from the Movenpick Hotel to begin the fully guided portion of our 4 day package. Explore the Hobart waterfront area before heading to the summit of Mt Wellington (1270m) boasting spectacular panoramic views in every direction. Further exploration through town sees us take in the historic Female Factory & Cascade Brewery while viewing many of Australia’s oldest convict built structures. Heading east we meander into the Coal River Valley, one of Tasmania’s premier wine regions. Naturally we will lunch at a lovely, family operated winery, sampling some of Tassie’s best wine & local produce before continuing on to the historic township of Richmond. We will see the beautiful stone arch construction of the Richmond Bridge, built by the convicts in 1823 this is Australia’s oldest bridge still in operation. Much to everyone’s delight we stop at the boutique Federation Chocolate factory just outside Richmond for some sampling of fresh, hand made chocolates. The flavours change depending on the season and the produce available! It’s then on to the Tasman Peninsula for our first taste of the east coast. The Tasman National Park boasts towering sea cliffs and a wealth of cultural history as we venture south. A beautiful lookout point over Pirates Bay provides the ideal location for a scenic, mid-afternoon tea/coffee break. Learn about Eaglehawk Neck - the site of the infamous Dogline - as we cross onto the Tasman Peninsula. We then explore some of nature’s true wonders with short, scenic walks at Tasman’s Arch & Devils Kitchen. Continuing on we squeeze in a stop at the colourful Port Arthur Lavender Farm before overnighting right on the cusp of the Port Arthur World Heritage Historic Site.

Port Arthur - Bicheno: Our day begins with a 3 hour fully guided tour around the Port Arthur Historic Site. Explore many of the original buildings as we learn about the early convicts and the role they played in Tasmania’s history. Learn about Point Puer (the juvenile boys prison), the Isle of the Dead graveyard and the Port Arthur timber industry while enjoying a short, scenic harbour cruise to view the site as incoming convicts would have. Next we leave the Tasman Peninsular for our journey up the very east coast of the island. At Raspins Beach we view the imposing Maria Island off the coast of Orford before stopping to see the unique convict built Spikey Bridge and the captivating coastline at Spikey Beach over tea, coffee & biscuits. Next up is Swansea – a beautiful East Coast town - and the Great Oyster Bay area. Arriving in Bicheno for our evening accommodation we will squeeze in one last feel good activity by spotting the cute little Fairy Penguins arriving ashore right in Bicheno township.

Bicheno & The Bay of Fires - Launceston: Start the day at the amazing Blow Hole on the rocky coastline of Bicheno. Visit the multi-award winning East Coast Nature World wildlife park to see many of our native animals and in particular - the feeding of the iconic Tasmanian Devil. Learn about this amazing animal and its recent struggle for survival. Pat wombats and hand-feed kangaroos, geese and ducks - this is a wonderful and interactive morning. Enjoy travelling Tasmania’s most scenic coastal road with breathtaking views of the east coast en route to one of Tasmania’s premier attractions - the Bay of Fires. At Binalong Bay we will stroll along the pure white sandy beaches and snap photos of possibly the most colourful spot on the island. Visit a working oyster farm, see their farming techniques and enjoy the freshest possible oysters. In the afternoon we proceed towards Launceston stopping at Pyengana, the award winning cheese factory and dairy. We then twist our way through an ancient Myrtle Rainforest and cross the trail of the dragon, an old mining area centred around the town of Derby. The carved memorial trees at Legerwood are one of Australia most unique & tasteful memorial sites, this will be our tea & coffee break for today. Arrive in Launceston CBD tonight approximately 6pm for the final evening our your 5 Day package at a perfectly located inner city hotel.

Departure: Enjoy an included hot breakfast at your inner city lodgings this morning. Your package officially concludes with hotel check-out by 11am. Feel free to contact us for suggested further activities or sight-seeing options.

tourName: Tasmania fishing holiday
placesVisited: Hobart, Expert Tasmania fly fishing guide, Macqurie River in Ross, Currawong Lakes, Brickendon, RiverFly Wilderness Camp, Walls of Jerusalem National Park, Launceston, Lake St. Clair, Pumphouse Point Wilderness Lodge
generalInfo:
This Tasmania fishing holiday takes you to the island that was the birthplace of trout fishing in the Southern Hemisphere. One hundred and fifty years ago brown trout ova were packed in moss and ice and transported successfully, on the third attempt, from the UK to Hobart, from where they were taken by horseback all over Tasmania, Australia, onwards to New Zealand and further field. In the year that celebrates this remarkable anniversary, one of the Tasmania's most breath-taking World Heritage wilderness lodges is also due to open, Pumphouse Point, located 250 metres from the shore of Lake St Clair, Australia's deepest lake, and one of the finest fly fishing spots in the world. Tasmania is known as The Land of 3000 Lakes with the deepest in Australia, packed full of wild trout, and as many crystal clear rivers and streams providing extraordinary fly fishing and lure fishing for anyone of all ages.

Nowhere else in the world offers such a huge range of diversity of fishing from remote wilderness camps on the edge of the World Heritage Wilderness, to convict built estates in heritage village that happens to have one of the world's best trout fishing rivers running through it to sustainable fishing eco lodges such as Currawong Lakes in the north east wilderness. While you are unlikely to see another human other than your guide for many of the days you are in Tasmania, you are never alone. Wedge-tailed eagles soar overhead, platypus duck and dive in the waters around you, and wombats, wallabies and Tasmanian devils rustle in the bush nearby, or stand on the shore watching you in nonchalant bemusement. Among the top fly fishing guides in Australia including the current Commonwealth Champion, Tasmania also has Australia's only professional fisherwoman, who takes pride in encouraging ladies and children to try their hands at fly fishing making it a holiday for couples and families too.

Whether you want to take one day out of you holiday to try your hand at fishing or two full weeks casting your fly in the very best of Tasmania's lakes and rivers from the north east to the Central Highlands you can be sure of stunning landscapes, weird and wonderful wildlife, superb food and drink and a comfortable bed on which to lay your head under a star filled inky black sky. Tasmania's trout fishing season runs from September to March.

dayInfo.description: Hobart: Arrive into Hobart from Melbourne or Sydney. This is Australia's prettiest state capital, nestled under Mt Wellington and on one of the most beautiful harbours in the world, and the River Derwent which begins in the heart of the Central Highlands, top fly fishing country. Enjoy a private 20 minute transfer from the airport to your charming family run accommodation just minutes from the historic waterfront. Visit one of the state's most important wildlife sanctuaries this afternoon and come face to face with the many species of animal you are likely to meet on your journey. Spend the evening soaking up the bohemian and maritime atmosphere of this delightful little city. A trip to the free Tasmanian Museum & Art Gallery will prepare you for some of the stunning natural history and landscapes you are about to witness.

Lake St Clair: After a night in Launceston, you will hire a car and journey through jaw dropping landscapes through the Central Highlands, Land of 3000 Lakes. Your destination is Pumphouse Point, Tasmania's newest wilderness lodge which is spectacularly located in the middle of Australia's deepest lake, Lake St Clair, in the World Heritage Wilderness. You will have two nights in this restored pumphouse and enjoy some of the best lake fishing in the world under the watchful eye of Ken Orr and his trusty guides from Orrsome Fishing. With 1000 km of walks, unpolluted skies and abundant wildlife, there are few places in the world that compare to this pristine and stunning natural environment.
Hobart: Today you will return to Hobart for your afternoon flight out to Sydney or Melbourne, or enjoy one last night in the city.

tourName: Tasmania self drive holiday for Australians
generalInfo:
Tasmania: home to the Tasmanian devil, award-winning produce, unpolluted air blown straight in from the Southern Ocean and vast swathes of accessible wilderness like nowhere you will have ever seen before.

Australia's only island state is a short flight from several Australian airports, making it an easy yet utterly unique holiday destination from the mainland. Those wishing to bring their own car can make an easy voyage across the Bass Strait from Victoria.

Despite its proximity to the mainland you could be venturing into another world, a hidden paradise, the land that time forgot.

What awaits is a mesmerising island of mysterious forests, deep lakes, wild rivers, pristine beaches, rolling hills, historic townships and picturesque villages with names as beguiling as Paradise, Nowhere Else, Promised Land and Penguin.

Discover a gentle lifestyle reminiscent of yesteryear, breathe the cleanest air in the inhabited world, invigorate your palate with the freshest produce on earth, come face to face with an abundance of wildlife that might have stepped straight from a fairy tale.

Where better to reconnect, restore and rejuvenate your body, mind and soul than the heart-shaped island of Tasmania.

On this magical Tasmanian odyssey you can begin your self-drive holiday from Hobart, Launceston or Devonport on a day to suit you, and explore for as little or as long as your time/budget allow, from a week or more. While we can most certainly incorporate the classic icons of Tasmania, the real joy of this holiday lies in our local knowledge and ability to take you to new horizons, down untrodden paths and the road less travelled to hidden gems that the guidebooks can't tell you about.

Each journey we create is designed to showcase the best of Tassie’s local hospitality and lifestyle, food and drink, wildlife and nature, World Heritage sites, culture and history.

‘Meet the locals’ in charming B&Bs. Dine on delicious home cooking. Get close to nature in self contained wilderness cottages and cabins. Relax in restored homesteads surrounded by art and antiques from a bygone era. Stroll out from your own beach house onto the most pristine beaches imaginable with only a wallaby or two for company.

The style and pace of our holidays are tailored to suit any age and ability, from the young and active to the mature and mellow, even those with limited mobility. Just a few days to spare? You will come home feeling you have had the experience of a lifetime.

We have been making dreams come true in Tassie for over 20 years. Put your dreams in the hands of Tasmanian travel experts. No one knows Tassie like we do. Our passion is to share it with you.

The following itinerary starts in Hobart but we can easily start it in the north. Remember this is just a guideline - do let us have any special interests and requests no matter how unusual so we can create a Tasmanian odyssey just for you.

dayInfo.description: If you are starting in Hobart, your journey begins as your plane starts its descent over densely forested mountain ranges stretching as the eye can see, carved up by wild rivers and liberally peppered with inky lakes. As the plane banks you should catch your first glimpse of endless arcs of the east coast’s white sand beaches washed by an impossibly turquoise Tasman Sea. Coming into land, you will barely have time to pinch yourself before you arrive at one of the prettiest and most vibrant cities in Australia. This is the maritime state capital, Hobart, perched insouciantly between The Mountain and the Great Southern Ocean. This is also the gateway to arguably the most beautiful and diverse island paradise in the world. And this is where your Tasmanian odyssey begins. Within half an hour you can be standing on the historic sandstone Salamanca Place where you can enjoy the best of all worlds: the pretty village of Battery Point, the year round buzz of Salamanca’s restaurants, bars and galleries, and the arresting beauty of one of the world’s most beautiful harbours with Mt Wellington as its backdrop. For those with an interest in convict history, Hobart is within a 90 minute drive of the World Heritage listed Port Arthur Historic Site. Don’t make the mistake of trying to see it in a day's drive however; far better to continue your drive down to the Tasman Peninsula where we can arrange some delightfully off-beaten-track accommodation far from the madding crowd or save it for later in your tour.

If your stay in Hobart falls over a weekend you can enjoy the bustle of Tasmania’s longest running attraction – the Salamanca markets, where locals gather to chat, laugh and entertain each other with an ambience akin to a village fete. Spend the afternoon at MONA – the world famous Museum of Old and New Art, one of the world’s most extraordinary private museums, built within the Triassic sandstone cliffs of the River Derwent. Take the ferry up the river and book seats in the Posh Pit – you won’t be disappointed!

This morning you will leave Hobart and start your westerly ascent. Your journey up the scenic and lush Derwent Valley will take you to one of Tasmania’s oldest and best loved national parks, Mt Field, where easy short walks will reveal 80 metre high Russell Falls and the tallest flowering trees in the world – legendary giants of the forest. There is even more magic to see for those who can explore deeper and higher in to the park. Stay in a riverside cabin at the very entrance to the National Park, or a restored homestead tucked away in the midst of the rolling hills and lakes of the southern Central Highlands.

Today is free to explore this beautiful region. We can arrange a private guided tour of the local producers for which the Derwent Valley is famous. Or continue up the magnificent Lyell Highway, the road to the wild west coast, to one of Tasmania’s most remarkable art installations, the Wall in the Wilderness. This modern-day one-man work of art is a 100 metre wooden sculpture telling the story of the Central Highlands set among the jaw dropping landscapes of the Wild Rivers National Park. Head down to the Far South West, Lake Pedder, birthplace of the world’s first Green Party and the start of the eco-tourism movement as we know it. Those with a love of gentle adventure and wildlife mustn't miss the chance to experience a paddle at dusk with the undisputed royalty of the river - the Duck-Billed Platypus!

Those on a seven day itinerary may now make the easy drive through across the pretty settlements of the southern Midlands to the east coast and continue from there (see Day 17). Those on our ten or fourteen day itinerary will love driving the road less travelled north through the Central Plateau, traversing the barely habited Land of Three Thousand Lakes, famous for some of the finest trout fishing in the world - an other-worldly, surreal landscape (see Day 9 onwards). If you are lucky enough to be extending your stay for a few more days, your drive will take you on to the wild West Coast of Tasmania, via Australia’s deepest freshwater lake, Lake St Clair, from where this sample itinerary continues.

Today you will continue your slow climb through the dramatic landscapes and across the ‘moonscape’ of Queenstown. No fewer than ninety bends later, you will reach the tiny town of Strahan. This little outpost sits on the edge of Macquarie Harbour, an astonishing piece of water which is several times larger than Sydney Harbour and has no landmass between it and South America. Soak up the spine-chilling story of this remote outpost that witnessed the torturous lives of men sentenced to horrific penal labour, only a century later to witness men and women literally stop environmental destruction in its tracks. Take the West Coast Wilderness Railway under steam through virgin rainforest – a living piece of history that will bring the stories of piners and miners alive as your carriage negotiates some of the steepest gradients of any railway in the world under the Swiss designed rack and pinion system.

The drive north from Strahan will take you along the gravel road known locally as The Road to Nowhere and across the Pieman River on a single vehicle ferry. You will stay at a wilderness retreat, a former mining village, deep in the heart of one of the last major stretches of temperate rainforest left on the planet.

Boarding a historic little restored Huon Pine vessel, you will voyage deep into the mysterious and bitterly fought over Tarkine Rainforest, which makes up 7% of Tasmania’s landmass. As you cruise down the majestic waters of this wild river, you will marvel at the shimmering reflections and walk among the most ancient trees in the world with inquisitive endemic wildlife and birds for company.

Today you will continue the astonishing journey north on the Road to Nowhere through virgin rainforest and high over the wilderness to a place of such rugged and wild beauty that it is known as the Edge of the World. For all the world it feels like it. The Roaring Forties winds sweep in from Patagonia, with nothing in between there and here to stem their power, bringing crashing waves to these wild, uninhabited shores. Later today, possibly without passing another vehicle, you reach the Far North West. Breathe deeply, for you are now on the spot which consistently records the cleanest air in the inhabited world! Stanley, a perfect little gem of a town, sits peacefully at the base of a dramatic ‘Nut’ of volcanic rock at the end of a peninsula in the Bass Strait, bursting with history of early settlers and the contentment of generations of families for whom this remote and once almost uninhabitable corner of the world became home through sheer determination and resilience. Nowhere is the warmth and friendliness of islanders, the power of nature, and the cheeky curiosity of the wildlife more evident. Tasmanian Pademelons vie for your attention, wallabies hop down the street at dusk, and comical Little Penguins brazenly strut their stuff in front of your eyes in all their wild glory as they return from a day’s fishing in the mighty ocean.

Those of you departing from Tasmania today can make the easy drive to Devonport or Launceston. For those lucky adventurers for whom the odyssey is far from over, a wildlife spectacular awaits! You will leave the far North West corner and continue the journey into yet another world as you venture into ancient devil country. Stay on a private Land for Wildlife retreat in a beautiful lost valley where Tasmanian devils and quolls roam freely, undisturbed by man. During your stay in a simple but spacious log cabin you will take a guided walk at dusk to spot the elusive Duck-billed Platypus before settling down in front of your log fire with a delicious home-cooked dinner, served exclusively to gets on this tour, and prepare for Tasmania’s largest carnivorous marsupial to arrive on your porch – the rare and endangered Tasmanian devil, more often than not joined by its equally elusive cousin, the Quoll.

Today you will be able to explore one of Tasmania’s most breath-taking canyons, arguably the most spectacular bushwalking spot in Tasmania with a fraction of those who flock to Cradle Mountain (which is an easy day trip away for those who wish to see it). Choose from one of the easy walks to two of the most dramatic lookout points in the island on canopies which are cantilevered out high over the crashing river and forests below, or one of the many more challenging walks for those with a thirst for adventure. Visit beautiful private gardens, run by a dedicated family of ladies whose green fingered prowess has attracted film crews from all over the country to this most unlikely of locations.

Leaving the enigmatic Central Highlands of Tasmania, you will meander your way to a little known region – the Great Western Tiers. On the way, stop at more magnificent gardens where several platypus can be seen on a daily basis; and call in at some of the many local makers – cheese, honey, chocolate, salmon and cool climate wines. Spend tonight in a cosy three room eco B&B, far from the tourist trail, whose owner is as highly regarded for his cooking as for his knowledge of the forests, which he will share on a never to be forgotten guided walk. This evening he will swap his walking boots for chef’s whites as you enjoy visits from the local marsupials before tucking into a mouth-watering dinner of local produce.

Head towards Launceston, and stroll around ‘Cataract Gorge’, the ‘Wilderness in the Heart of the City’, taking the world’s longest chairlift across the impressive natural gorge. Culture vultures can visit two of Tasmania’s World Heritage Listed convict sites where the most precious and perfectly preserved convict history in Australia is set among acres of fabulous gardens including the National Rose Garden. Your destination tonight is the aptly named Beauty Point. Despite its name and location, Beauty Point attracts surprisingly few visitors. You will love its delightful arty, local vibe – added to which you are within a short drive of the Narawntapu National Park and a beautiful swimming beach. Stay in one of the island’s most highly rated B&Bs, a true hidden gem which epitomises Tasmanian hospitality at its best, set in carefully tended cottage gardens which run down to the Tamar River.

Today you can indulge in a private winery tour taking in the best of the famous Tamar Valley wine route, or spend the day exploring local attractions including Platypus House, home to platypus and echidna; Beaconsfield Gold Mine and Seahorse World. Those on a slower pace will love the chance to simply relax and enjoy the B&B’s riverfront gardens and BBQ gazebo.

Visitors on a two week itinerary can depart from Launceston or Devonport this evening, but if you have longer to spare in this enchanted land, read on, for It’s time to explore Tasmania’s jaw-dropping scenic east coast with its sugar-white beaches lined with vivid orange granite rocks lapped by turquoise seas, wineries, cellar doors and olive groves. Make the easy and peaceful drive through the north east wilderness to the east coast town of St Helens, gateway to the 50 km stretch of beaches known as the Bay of Fires. You can stay in St Helens itself, but those wishing to further connect with nature can enjoy a spot of glamping in the forest, just minutes from the sea although like all things Tasmanian, creature comforts are always to hand with cashmere hot water bottles and sublime cooking, dished up in the Bush Kitchen.

Today why not explore the secret waterways and rivers of the North East wilderness on a guided kayak tour, on ultra stable kayaks perfect for novice paddlers and photographers. Afterwards, walk along the wild beaches and through the Mt William National Park, home to Forester Kangaroos and many other species of wildlife.

You are now embarking on Tasmania’s Great Eastern Drive. There are several choices to make, depending on your mobility, interests and most importantly, how many people you wish to see on your travels! Wineglass Bay on the Freycinet Peninsula is one of Tasmania’s most photographed spots and an unmissable highlight for many, but if your idea of heaven is mile upon mile of untrodden wild beaches and walking trails, swimming in secret water holes and an island known as the ‘wombat capital of the world’, our recommendation is to discover the hidden delights north of the iconic Freycinet Peninsula, or equally the historic southern stretch with spellbinding views spanning the Hazards Mountain Range down to the Maria Island National Park.

Take to the seas for a small group guided boat trip into the Tasman Sea and along this glorious 250 million year old coastline spotting marine life such as Albatross, Australian fur seals, dolphin and possibly whales. Depending on your preferred trip, enjoy lunch at anchor in one of the world’s most photographed bays, or step ashore a ‘Noah’s Ark’ island national park, and walk around another World Heritage Convict Site, spotting wombats, kangaroos, wallabies and possibly devils.

One last great adventure awaits: Bruny Island lies an hour south of Hobart, accessed by an easy 15 minute ferry. Bruny consists of two islands joined by an isthmus. It is home to Australia’s only White Wallabies and all 12 endemic birds. It is widely regarded as Tasmania’s very own ‘larder’ with wine, whiskey, cheese, berries, chocolate and much more. As with all our accommodation suggestions we advise avoiding the day trippers and guide-book tourists. Instead, spend your last couple of nights in a waterfront hideaway complete with private BBQ and firepit. Your luxury retreat overlooks the sparkling water, and is surrounded by your very own private wildlife safari of endemic mammals including Quolls, Pademelons and Poteroos. As a special treat a locally grown organic veg box will be included and an exclusive private wildlife viewing. As a grand finale to your Tasmanian odyssey, it doesn’t get better than this.

Today you are free to explore Bruny Island at your leisure, with the option of an eco adventure cruise into the Great Southern Ocean, or simply walking the many trails along the highest cliffs in the Great Southern Ocean, tasting the delicious produce and looking southwards towards that other great wilderness of the world – Antarctica. As a grand finale to your Tasmanian odyssey, it simply doesn’t get better than this.

You will fly out of Hobart later today. For one last lunch, head to the Coal River Valley wineries and the pretty village of Richmond just 15 minutes from the departure terminal at Hobart Airport. Bid au revoir, not farewell, for once you have stepped foot on this glorious isle, you can be sure you will return.

tourName: Tasmania wildlife tour
placesVisited: Hobart, Bruny Island, White wallabies, Great Southern Ocean Tasmanian wildlife cruise, Mount Field National Park, Lake St. Clair, Tasmanian Wilderness UNESCO World Heritage Site, Central Highlands, Strahan, Road to Nowhere, Stanley, Tarkine Rainforest, Arthur River Cruise, Leven Canyon, Tasmanian Devils, Narawntapau National Park, Tamar River, Freycinet National Park, Tasmania birdwatching, Wineglass Bay, Whale watching, Bonorong Wildlife Sanctuary
generalInfo:
Tasmania is one of the world's true Noah's Arks, with many species that can be found nowhere else in the world, and this Tasmania wildlife tour helps you discover it all. When the land bridge flooded that separated Tasmania from the mainland, it became a life raft for species that would be wiped out by the arrival of the early settlers on mainland Australia.

Prolific, unafraid, at once beautiful, comical, weird and wonderful, Tasmania's wildlife will leave you captivated. With careful planning and local inside knowledge, the species of marsupial and monotreme that you can see in the wild include Tasmanian devils, Quolls, Wombats, Possums, Kangaroos, Wallabies, Pademelons, Bettongs, Poteroos, the Duck-billed Platypus and Echidna. Even the more common Australian species are highly unusual in their own way - such as the wild White Wallabies found only on Bruny Island. Even for non-birders, birds hold an irresistible appeal - such as the Cape Barren Goose, the Orange-bellied Parrot - the rarest bird in the world that breeds only in Tasmania, and the Native Hen.

This Tasmanian Wildlife Tour will take you to far flung corners of this extraordinarily diverse island, a landmass the size of Ireland, Switzerland or Sri Lanka. You will stay at little known properties on land that has been protected by its owners, guardians of nature and accidental eco-warriors, for decades. The accommodation may be rustic and simple in the more remote places but no less charming, and its true beauty is that the wildlife is free to roam and live without fear, meaning you are the privileged visitor who shares its habitat and learns from those who have spent much of their lives striving to protect it.

You will, with luck, witness the remarkable experience of Tasmanian devils, the largest remaining carnivorous marsupial with a jaw strength second to none, feeding in the wild. You will watch the world's plumpest Platypus swimming gracefully in rivers and lakes. You will quite possibly walk through a mob of Forester Kangaroos and wild white Wallabies and count dozens of Wombats grazing yards away from you without a care in the world. You will watch Little Penguins coming back from a day's fishing in the Bass Strait to their burrows and watch White-bellied Sea Eagles swoop to take fish thrown from your boat. You will take to the seas along the highest cliffs in the Southern Hemisphere to gasp in wonder at Albatross, Sea Eagles, pods of Dolphin and, in certain months, Southern Right, Humpback and Killer Whales on their migration north. You may not see a Tasmanian Tiger but you will certainly believe it exists.

While the tour is largely based on a self-drive, those who wish to leave their keys behind for a couple of days and put themselves in the hands of experts will benefit from superb private guiding by one of Australia's top bush trackers, and one of the country's most highly respected conservationists and birding experts. Those who love walking can spend four days glamping on Tasmania's very own Noah's Ark, an island off an island, where, like much of Tasmania, wildlife has been left to roam and breed freely and uninterrupted by man.

dayInfo.description: Day 1: Hobart. Arrive in Australia's prettiest state capital that sits at the bottom of Mt Wellington and on one of the most beautiful harbours in the world. Enjoy a day or urban birding in the local parks, reserves and waterways with a local guide. Hire your car and drive to your family run accommodation just minutes from the waterfront. Spend tonight exploring and soaking up the bohemian, maritime lifestyle that has made Hobart one of the prettiest and most alluring State Capitals in Australia. Or stay on an award-winning 'Raptor Refuge' just 25 minutes from Hobart where you will come face to face with the Kings of the Skies, rescued and under rehabilitation before release back to the wild.

Day 2: Bruny Island. Drive 50 minutes to Kettering and take the little car ferry to one of Tasmania's offshore islands. Bruny Island is a little-known gem, home to all 12 endemic birds and prolific wildlife. Drive to your cottage and explore the cloud forests, wild beaches and enjoy a close encounter in the wild with the world's only White Wallabies.

Day 3: Highest Cliffs in the Southern Hemisphere. Today you will take the water for an adventure cruise along the highest cliffs in the Southern Hemisphere which tower to 300 metres, with huge dolerite spires and deep caves. Cruise to the edge of the Great Southern Ocean - look south to Antarctica - and enjoy the magical sight of Albatross, Shearwaters and Sea Eagles. Pods of Dolphin wil accompany you to the largest colonies of Fur Seals in Australia and between April and November you are likely to see Whales. After an exhilarating few hours at sea with your guides - local fishermen and conservationists - you will return to your cottage on Bruny, and enjoy some locally bought produce; Bruny is also known as Tasmania's gourmet larder.

Day 4: Mt Field and Lake St Clair Leave Bruny Island and start your drive towards the Southern Central Highlands on your way to the Western Wilderness. Stop at The Mt Field National Park to walk among the tallest flowering trees in the world and magnificent Russell Falls. Count how many animals you see and keep eyes peeled for Platypus and Echidna. You can even enjoy a guided paddle with platypus at dusk. Stay in a private cottage or restored sheep farm with resident wallabies and platypus, and keep an eye out for the Southern Lakes.

Day 5: Strahan, Gateway to the Rainforest. Continue your journey deep into the Western Wilderness crossing wild rivers and deep gorges. Arrive in Strahan, a tiny fishing village on a harbour six times the size of Sydney's. There is nothing between you and South America. Take a trip down the Gordon River deep into the ancient rainforest or travel under steam on the original tracks that traverse some of the steepest gradients in the world and learn about the rich mining heritage of this wild and remote area.

Day 6: The Road to Nowhere. Before you leave, stop at the Strahan Visitor Centre to learn about the environmentalists who started the world's first Green Party in 1982 when the world voted to stop the Franklin River Dam. Begin your drive along the 'Road to Nowhere', crossing the Pieman River and the Fatman Barge. Keep eyes skinned for Sea Eagles, Tasmanian devils and Quolls. You can stop at a true wilderness retreat and stay in restored miners' cottages, time permitting, or you can continue on a drive which will take you most of the day as you journey up the Edge of the World. Arrive in the fishing village of Stanley overlooking the magnificent plug of volcanic rock known as The Nut that rises out of the Bass Strait. Spend this evening at a family run inn and feast on the local shellfish and seafood before heading to the beach for the magical sight of Little Penguins returning from fishing in the Bass Strait and heading to their burrows.

Day 7: The Arthur River Cruise. Drive just one hour back into the Tarkine Rainforest and board the MV George Robinson for a trip down the Arthur River deep into the Tarkine Rainforest. You may well see Devils, Platypus, Quolls and even Tiger Snakes on the river bank. A highlight are the Wedge-tailed Eagles that wait for your arrival and the White-bellied Sea Eagles as they swoop down for their daily fish treats. Spend a second night in Stanley.

Day 8. Wild Tasmanian devils. Take an early morning hike up the volcanic plug, The Nut, with just innumerable wallabies and pademelons for company, before saying goodbye to the North West coast and heading inland, deep into the North West Wilderness. You are heading for a little known 'lost valley'. Here you will find a 'Land for Wildlife' conservation site, owned by a couple under whose stewardship its wildlife has flourished. The afternoon wildlife tour will probably reveal platypus playing just feet from your feet. You can venture into a deep glow-worm filled cave and come face to face with dozens of wallabies and Pademelons. As dusk falls, Tasmania devils and their cousin the Quolls will make their way to your cabin, drawn by tasty chunks of roadkill left on your veranda. Sit back in front of your fire, enjoy a glass of wine and enjoy the night time spectacle.

Day 9: Cradle Mountain. You are just over an hour's drive to the iconic Cradle Mountain. Enjoy a walk around Dove Lake climb further to Crater Lake. Visit Devils@Cradle, one of the state's top Tasmanian devil sanctuary where you will enjoy a close encounter with this unjustly maligned creature, and discover why the species is in mortal peril. If you have time, spend a couple of nights here and you will lose count of your wombat sightings! Otherwise, leave the tourists behind and return to your cabin in your secret valley for another evening of spectacular wildlife viewing.

Day 10: Walk in The Narawntapau National Park, known as the Serengeti of Tasmania due to the abundance of wildlife at dawn and dusk, with a hike to Archers Knob revealing views across the entire north coast of the island. As light falls, keep your camera at the ready - this is Kangaroo Central and a bit of patience at dusk or dawn will get you the prized 'boxing kangaroo' shots. Spend tonight at a delightful B&B at Beauty Point, on the banks of the Tamar River. Alternatively head out for a couple of days into the remote North East with the 'Crocodile Dundee' of Tasmania - one of the best wildlife guides in Australia - a true bush-tracker with private cabins in the bush surrounded by kangaroos, quolls, devils and platypus. This is the ultimate Tasmanian Wildlife Extravaganza!

Day 11: The East Coast. Begin your drive to the mild, sunny east coast of Tasmania where miles of white sand beaches are in stark contrast to the rainforest of the west coast. Drive through the north east wilderness to your very own beach cottage on one of the most startling long white sandy beaches you have ever seen. With direct beach access, here you can spend many a happy hour spotting Echidna, extensive birdlife, wombats, wallabies and Forester kangaroos, and exploring the Bay of Fires - one of the most beautiful stretches of wild coastline in Australia.

Day 13: Freycinet Peninsula. Head south for an hour or so to Tasmania's east coast icon, the Freycinet Peninsula, famous for Wineglass. Here, in the Freycinet National Park, you will also see many of Tasmania's endemic birds as well as many Forester Kangaroos, Wallabies and other marsupials. After the cruise, head south to Triabunna and stay in restored accommodation just a few minutes from the marina.

Day 14: Maria Island National Park. Only accessible by boat, and with no permanent residents, this island national park is a haven for endangered birds and wildlife. Explore by foot or by bike, or if time allows, spend the next three nights on a magical four day guided walk and spot Tasmanian devils by night.

Day 15: Hobart bound. Make your hour-long drive to Hobart Airport, or, if you have a couple more days to spare, head to the Huon Valley and stay in a carbon positive forest retreat where yet more bird, marsupial and reptile life abounds. If time is precious, one more treat lies in store before you say farewell however. Bonorong is one of the island's most important wildlife sanctuaries where all animals are rescued, rehabilitated and released if possible. It also has a Tasmanian devil breeding programme and the island's official wildlife SOS line and Animal Hospital. A pre-booking on this tour only will ensure you are upgraded you to a private keeper tour, enabling you to have one last close encounter with your favourite animal, or see any species that you may have missed on your wildlife tour of Tasmania. From here you are just 30 minutes' drive from Hobart Airport - unless you choose to extend your visit of course.

tourName: Western Australia self drive holiday
generalInfo:
This 16-day tailor made itinerary starts in Perth, known for its white sand beaches, curated street art & scenic parks. With places such as Fremantle only 30 minutes away, it’s an environmentally friendly city that overflows with charm.

Just a short distance off the coast of Perth City, you will discover secluded coves, picturesque scenery and dazzling marine life. Enjoy a day exploring the beautiful Rottnest Island, a protected nature reserve and home of the world-famous Quokka.

Head to Nambung National Park and spend the day exploring. As well as the Pinnacles Desert, you will uncover some of its beautiful beaches at Kangaroo Point and Hangover Bay. You may also like to enjoy a trail along the boardwalk at Lake Thetis. The vegetation creates a memorable spectacle for all that visit.
Next you’ll make your way to Kalbarri National Park, one of Western Australia’s most popular places for colourful wildflowers. Head over to Hawkes Head Lookout for some popular views of the sandstone cliffs.

Enjoy exploring the World Heritage listed Ningaloo Reef, swarming with turtles, tropical fish, manta rays and humpback whales. This is one of the only places on earth that these creatures congregate in such large numbers.
Finish your trip with a relaxing evening watching the sun set on Cottesloe Beach, whilst enjoying a glass of wine, refreshing beer or a relaxed dinner and reflect on what will have been a trip of a lifetime. This is a trip that will leave you with memories that you won’t forget.

dayInfo.description: Today you begin your journey by boarding your international outbound flight to Perth.
On-board your international outbound flight to Perth.

On arrival in Perth you will be transferred by private vehicle to your downtown accommodation. The remainder of the day is free to relax. Why not shake off the jetlag with a walk around the new Elizabeth Quay district to explore the harbourfront, before heading to the state buildings for dinner.
You have the day at leisure today. You may like to hop on the train or ferry to Fremantle and spend your day wandering around the markets and historic centre.

Today you have a full day exploring Rottnest Island by foot, boat and bicycle. Spend some time relaxing on the stunning white sand beaches of this nature reserve just off the coast of Perth, and keep an eye out for the island's most famous inhabitant, the Quokka.

Collect your hire car and drive north to Nambung National Park to spend the day exploring the remarkable Pinnacles Desert. Please note that your hire-car is subject to a one-way drop off fee which will need to be paid locally.
Continue to Kalbarri National Park and take one of the walking trails past canyons and dramatic rock formations.
Spend the day exploring Kalbarri National Park. Walk to Nature's Window for a stunning view over the gorge below.
Today you journey northwards through Kalbarri National Park, and then along the coastal highway to Monkey Mia.

Today you will have the chance to explore the rusty red soils, white sand beaches and stunning turquoise seas of the lesser known Francois Peron National Park. Your aboriginal guide will be sure to teach you stories of the dreamtime, how to find bush tucker and how to use traditional bush medicine.

Head from Monkey Mia to Coral Bay today. We recommend breaking up the drive by stopping at Carnarvon for a stop to learn about the wool making industry of the area or visit the nearby stromatolites at Hamelin Pool.
Arrive into Exmouth today, home of the Ningaloo Reef Marine Park. Spend the day today relaxing on the beach ready to explore the waters tomorrow.
Today you will take a boat out onto the World Heritage listed Ningaloo Reef, with the chance to snorkel on the pristine reef off the Muiron Islands.
Drive to nearby Learmonth this morning and fly from there to Perth. Travel out to Cottesloe Beach to watch the sun set over the Indian Ocean and reflect on your trip.
You will be collected from your city accommodation in time for your onward flight.
Arrive home today to complete your journey.

tourName: Western Australia wildlife holiday
generalInfo:
Join an expert local guide in Western Australia and explore both the land and sea here in search of Tiger Sharks, Whale Sharks, Greater Bilbies, Numbats as well as experiencing the wonderful deserts, forests and coral reefs along the Western Coast.

Introduction:

We are specialists in tailoring wildlife watching all over the world and we have a great range of wildlife tours in Australia which combine various different wildlife events and in this case along the glorious coast of Western Australia. In order to develop our unrivalled range of combined wildlife watching holidays, our guides and colleagues around the world have spent years searching out the world’s best wildlife watching locations as well as visiting some seldom visited areas. This dedication has led us to create this wonderful tour that starts in the capital of Western Australia and the fantastic city of Perth, before heading the short distance across the sea to Rottnest Island and then back on the mainland down south to the unique forests of Dryandra before travelling back north and all the way to Exmouth, via Jurien Bay, Nambung & Kalbarri National Parks and the oceanic hotspots of Shark Bay and Ningaloo Reef (before flying back to Perth).

This tour stops off at some of the best wildlife watching locations along this wonderful coastline. Anyone interested in the marine world will no doubt know that there are very few better destinations that Western Australia. But we will also explore some of the best kept wildlife secrets in Australia by travelling inland in search of some wonderfully named animals such as numbats, woylies, bettongs, boodies and bilbies. But of course it is the sea that dominates life in Australia and we will aim to experience some of the worlds most spectacular oceanic species; from the worlds largest fish to some of the worlds most pristine coral reefs and endangered species like dugongs, manta rays and top predators like tiger sharks. The marine life is so prolific here that many of the species can be seen from the boat and we do not bait or chum for any of the sharks and still usually see over 5 different species. All of our tours are guided by our own professional local guide so you are sure to be in the best hands possible for the best sightings. Our escort for this tour has experience working on with sharks in South Africa and in Australia as well as working with whales and dolphins in the UK. If possible we will try and arrange a trip out with the Shark Bay Ecosystem Research Project (SBERP) whilst in Shark Bay; this is a project that our director worked on and will try and take you out with them to see how they conduct their research on the sharks, turtles and stingrays in the bay (subject to availability).

We also have a great network of local guides in Australia who have developed a great range of wildlife watching locations where the rarest species are commonly seen. We will spend as much time after dark in certain locations as you wish and with the help a of high powered spotlight we will search for nocturnal species. One of the reasons why our wildlife watching holidays are unique is that our background (as a company) is from a scientific and zoological standpoint and so have a great network of colleagues and contacts all over the world who are the people on the front line in search of the best new locations for wildlife watching. All of these reasons and many more make us experts in arranging safaris and are able to tailor a safari to any location to try to find your targeted species. All you have to do is to get in touch with your budget and your group size and where you would like to go to try and find rare and elusive species.

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including three meals per day (breakfast, lunch and dinner). There will be bottled water (approx 1ltr) available for each guest each day. We have our own private air conditioned vehicles with an excellent driver for all transfers. Where possible we use two brilliant guides; first a professional guide will escort you on all your excursions and will act as your driver throughout and also very knowledgeable English speaking local guides who have decades of experience working and guiding through Western Australia. Your guide is an expert in animal behaviour as well as marine biology and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. The local guides have spent years searching out the best wildlife watching locations and have an unrivalled knowledge of where some of the most elusive Australian animals are. As well as having years of experience in bringing people out to see sharks, whales, sea lions and endemic Australian marsupials and other wildlife safely. We have included trips to Dryandra Woodland Sanctuary where some of the rarest species in the world are being bred back from the brink of extinction. We also include all vehicle safaris, guided walks, spotlighting drives, whale shark snorkelling, swimming with sea lions, whale watching excursions, park entrance fees and sightseeing entrance fees. Also any trips out with researchers and scientists to see the wildlife (including tiger sharks) of Shark Bay will also be included (subject to availability). We include more time spent in the field searching for wildlife per day than any other tour operator around; only if you request to have a rest day will we not arrange a safari into the Australian bush or trip out to sea for whales or sharks. A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on the wildlife that you are likely to see which are available to watch throughout the tour.

Seasons:

Season; Early May to mid August. There are two main focuses of this trip, firstly the rare and endemic marsupials of Australia as well as the myriad of marine life from Perth north to Ningaloo and Exmouth. The marsupials do not have a specific season and can be seen all year around so we are dependent on the marine life and along the west coast of Australia everything is dependant on the plankton bloom of Ningaloo Reef. This occurs during the southern Hemisphere winter and from May to mid August there are many plankton feeding whale sharks and manta rays taking advantage of the plankton, these species are added to the resident Australian sea lions, bottlenose dolphins, humpback dolphins, marine turtles, reef sharks and dugongs. However we can further refine this period to incorporate the beginning of the humpback whale and tiger shark migrations from north to south by participating in this tour in from mid June to mid August.

Why Choose this Tour:

• All of our wildlife watching holidays are guided by a local naturalist guides and also scientists or researchers where possible, this not only gives you numerous sets of trained eyes to find the animals but also gives you the chance to understand the behaviours and habits of the wildlife your watching.
• We will endeavour to organise a trip out with the Shark Bay Ecosystem Research Project (SBERP) as they conduct surveys of Shark Bay as they study the tiger sharks, many stingray species and two species of marine turtle. This is the best way to see free-swimming tiger sharks without the use of bait or chum as well as seeing some of the many species that inhabit the bay.
• We can offer you spotlighting trips of the Dryandra Woodland Reserve and Kalbarri National Park so that you can search for the rarer species and other nocturnal wildlife when they are more active.
• We will also visit the Dryandra Woodland Sanctuary were a number of species are being bred for future reintroduction; the animals here (greater bilbies, boodies, numbats, woylies and bettongs) are living in a semi-wild habitat and you will be able to get up close and personal with some of the rarest species of mammal in the entire world.
• We can also bring thermal imaging and night vision equipment as well as hydrophones (on request) to also aid in finding the nocturnal mammals after dark and listen in on the underwater conversations of whales and dolphins.
• We use camera traps (where available) which will increase the chances of getting close up pictures and movies of rare animals and other rare nocturnal wildlife.
• Take the ferry from Perth over to Rottnest Island for a couple of days and see the idyllic Australian dream in full.
• Swim alongside the world’s largest species of fish, the whale shark off the wonderful Ningaloo Reef. This is all but a guaranteed experience during this time of the year and you will probably have the chance of swimming with a few of these magnificent sharks throughout the day.
• Explore the Pinnacles of Nambung National Park, this natural rock formation is stunning with over 150,000 (some up to 5m tall) stone pillars dotting the landscape.
• Snorkel with a colony of very inquisitive Australian sea lions at the stunning Jurien Bay Marine Park.
• Have a sunset catamaran cruise around beautiful Shark Bay, where the sky and sea melt into a pastel shaded horizon and dolphins, dugongs and turtles can be seen hundreds of meters away on the mirror like surface.
• Hopefully we will see one of the most unusual behaviours in the world and watch bottlenose dolphins beach themselves in pursuit of fish in François Peron National Park (as seen on the BBC’s Planet Earth Series).
• Snorkel the impressive Ningaloo Reef which is the world’s largest fringing reef, this means you can walk to the reef from the beach and enjoy most of the same species that the Great Barrier Reef has to offer from within 50m of the beach.
• All the above reasons give our Western Australian wildlife tour a great success rate of seeing the best wildlife around here. We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides throughout Australia so that we can try and find and observe animals such as the greater bilbies, boodies, numbats, whale sharks, tiger sharks, humpback whales, dolphins, Australian sea lions and hundreds of other species throughout Western Australia. Whether it is the Queensland, Northern Territory, Tasmania, South Australia, Great Barrier Reef, New South Wales and Victoria or any of the other many wildlife watching locations you want to visit we can arrange it. Please inform us if you wish to receive more information about any of these locations and booking a safari.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

This tour travels from Perth to Rottnest Island, Dryandra Woodland Reserve, the national parks of Nambung and Kalbarri as well as visiting the marine wildlife hotspots of Jurien Bay, Shark Bay and Ningaloo Reef.

Fitness Level:

There are a few physical activities on this tour, firstly the ability to swim and snorkel in essential (no scuba-diving experience is needed) and the ability to swim in open water for over 1 hour is needed. There is also walking and cycling involved and the temperatures in Western Australia can be hot, even during their winter. So we require people to be used to walking in the heat.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; the equipment list will vary from tour to tour and from location to location so it is best to contact us or wait until you receive the pre-departure pack after booking.

Minimum Age: 18 Years Old.

dayInfo.description: Perth – Arrival – This morning you will be met at the airport by your local guide and transferred to the hotel. As nearly all flights into Perth are very long in duration you will have today to recover and just relax in Perth. Perth is by far the largest place in Western Australia. The city is so clean and easy to navigate you will thoroughly enjoy your day relaxing, walking by the sea, exploring the shops and parks or simply sleeping off the flight in the hotel. (Lunch and or Dinner included (depending on the time of arrival)).

Shark Bay ¬– Travelling & Wildlife Watching – On the morning of day 11 you will leave Kablarri national Park after breakfat and travel further north and into the World Heritage area of Shark Bay. This will be your home for the next 4 nights, we will explore various aspects of this incredible and huge bay. Shark Bay is famous for its huge (largest in the world) pristine sea grass ecosystem which holds such a huge amount of life you will almost not believe your eyes and one of the most incredible spectacles will be seen on day 11. Just as we enter the peninsula we will stop at Hamelin Pool Marine Nature Reserve. This small bay is home to true living fossils. The bizarre looking statues which dot the waters edge are in fact living organisms called stromatolites; they are cyanobacteria and they form the structures by trapping microscopic calcium particles from sea shells and sand, they are the most simple form of life which use photosynthesis in order to produce food and the hyper-saline water of Hamelin Pool is perfect for them. They are living fossils because their closest relatives are fossil stromatolites over 3,500 million years old! The water is quite chilly but you are free to have a dip and get some underwater shots of the stromatolites. As well as these there are other animals in the pool including large thorntail stingrays which can grow to over 2m across their disc. They are very curious and often come right up to the waters edge. Once we leave Hamelin Pool we will continue on to Denham and our hotel for the next 4 nights. The next morning you will rise early and after breakfast drive down the road to the other settlement in Shark Bay; Monkey Mia. It is here that you can meet the stars of the bay as every morning a group of Indo-Pacific bottle-nose dolphins come very close to the beach and are fed by the locals. This is very controversial and we do not condone the feeding of the dolphins as it is proven to alter their behaviour, however it does allow you to get closer to wild dolphins than is usually possible. The rest of the day will be spent in the resort and we can go for walks along the beach and see what we can find which often includes, western shovelnose rays, coach-tail whiprays, reticulated whiprays, spotted eagle rays, cow-tailed stingrays, nervous sharks, Australian pelicans, pied cormorants and of course the dolphins. We can also hire sea kayaks and head out onto the water at a very leisurely pace to see if we can get close to dugongs, dolphins, green and loggerhead turtles and maybe even find the king og the bay, one of the large tiger sharks. There is very little to be worried about in the bay (considering there are over 10,000 tiger sharks and other species present in the bay there has only ever been one recorded shark attack and he was a spear fisherman. Our director has spent many hours on the water here including doing diving and snorkelling as part of a the Shark Bay Ecosystem Research Project and can vouch for the safety of the water (as long as your sensible). We will eat lunch here at Monkey Mia and when we have finished exploring the coastline we will leave for Denham and have our evening meal here. After breakfast on day 13 you will be taken to explore the interior of the peninsula inside Francois Peron National Park. Most of the roads are suitable for 2 wheel drive vehicles but if the conditions are not right we may be limited in where we can visit. However usually we can get to Skipjack Point, Cape Peron, Bottle Bay and the Gregories. Skipjack Point and Cape Peron are the best places to spot large sharks (tigers, bull, sandbar, lemon, nervous, scalloped hammerheads and others), stingrays (spotted eagle rays, coachtail whiprays, reticulated whiprays, cow-tailed), shovelnose rays (great and western), dugongs as well as green and loggerhead turtles. If we are lucky it is from here that a group of Indo-Pacific bottle-nose dolphins have learnt to herd fish into the shallows and beach themselves to snap them up. This was famously filmed for Planet Earth and we may be treated to a live viewing. As we are driving around the peninsula we past many birridas (salt-pans) and here many migratory birds aggregate. Peron is one of the best places to see thorny devils, bobtail skinks, breaded dragons, woma pythons and common walleroos. We will have a picnic lunch and as the sun begins to set we will head back to Denham for our evening meal. For your last full day in Shark Bay you will once again spend the day at Monkey Mia again so after breakfast we will drive there and today we will be having a cruise around the bay one of the catamarans which conducts wildlife tours of the bay. We will have an afternoon tour which specialises in finding dugongs. We will either stay on the boat for sunset and a relaxing cruise as the sunsets against the still waters creating a surreal pinkish grow which is reflected everywhere or we can join a cultural tour with an indigenous member of the Shark Bay population; he will take us into Dream Time and show us how the desert provides his people with food, water, shelter and everything they could need. Our evening meal will be in Denham and afterwards we can go back out into the desert and try to spotlight some of the rare mammals like Shark Bay mice, bilbies, boodies and short-beaked echidnas. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included)

Exmouth & Ningaloo Reef – Travelling, Snorkelling & Wildlife Watching – After an early breakfast in Denham we will leave Shark Bay and head north to our next destination and last stop on the northerly journey. Today is a long day of driving and so we will split the day with a morning drive to Carnarvon (4.5 hours) where we will have lunch and a break before we continue north to Exmouth (4.5-5 hours). As the drive will take the majority of the day the rest of the evening is free for you to rest and relax either in your hotel. The next day we will spend the day with the largest fish in the world. By travelling out to the edges of Ningaloo Reef, you will be in one of the best whale shark watching places in the world. From May to August they aggregate here to take advantage of the plankton blooms of the reef. We will have an opportunity to snorkel above the outer reef wall until the spotter plane fins a whale shark. The snorkelling may prove very rewarding as it is not unusual to see grey-reef sharks, white-tipped reef sharks, bat fish, large schools of sea bream and other fish. But the real fun begins as soon as we receive news of a sighting. The pilot of the plane will radio in the sighting and circle the shark until we arrive. Once we arrive you will be briefed on the strict rules of swimming with the animals which is as much for the safety of you as for the shark. Swimming with these gentle giants is amazing and you get a genuine sense of awe as they dwarf you and power forward with the smallest flicks of their tail and you struggle to keep up as you swim as fast as you can! We will recoup some energy with lunch on the boat and continue to snorkel with the huge sharks and sometimes we will end the day with more snorkelling around the reef itself, where huge stingrays and many reef fish are plentiful. As well as the highlight of whale sharks there are very good chances we can see and maybe swim with manta rays and even humpback whales at this time of the year; and then on retuning to the hotel you will you’re your well deserved evening meal. During day 17 you will be driven around the peninsula and taken to Cape Range National Park. Cape Range is a beautiful part of the world, partly because of all of the wonderful wildlife found around here such as black-footed rock wallabies, western grey kangaroos, Australian bustards, emus, galahs, perenties and red kangaroos and partly because of the close proximity of Ningaloo Reef. The reef here extends right up to the coastline and this makes snorkelling here amazing. In between all the green turtles, black-tipped reef sharks, blue-green parrotfish, Clarke’s anemone fish and many more species you will not know where to look. We will travel to a nearby café for lunch and in the afternoon continue exploring the park either by snorkelling or walking. Then on your last full day around here you have the choice of either going back to Cape Range National Park and enjoy more snorkelling, birding and walking in the scrub or stay in Exmouth and enjoy our last day relaxing in the quaint town before we travel back to Perth. We will eat our lunch in a café depending on where we are and our evening meal will be back at the hotel. (Breakfast, Lunch and Dinner)

Perth – Travelling & Day of Rest - This morning after breakfast you will be taken to the airport where we will catch the short flight (2.5 hours) back south to Perth. On arrival in Perth we will have the rest of the day to do as you please. You can take advantage of the great shopping here for souvenirs, or just head to one of the many city parks and relax and watch the colourful rosellas and lorikeets as they chirp and flit about. We will have your farewell evening meal at the hotel or nearby restaurant. (Breakfast, Lunch and Dinner)
Home – Departure – This morning you will be transferred to the airport in time to catch the return flight to home. (Breakfast only)

tourName: Western Tasmania 5 day tour
generalInfo:
Our 5 Day Western Tasmania Wilderness Tour provides an insight into a world many tourists never venture - the remote and photogenic west coast! Perhaps you’ve already toured the more popular east coast? Or maybe just prefer travelling through pristine, unpopulated areas filled with greenery and natural wonder? This tour could be a great option for you. Covering approximately 750km we explore many of Tassie’s premier central highlands & west coast attractions, moving fast enough to provide a fantastic overview of the island, yet slow enough to enjoy the sights! Suitable for all ages and fitness levels this is definitively a unique and eye opening, small group travel experience.

Highlights:
• Sampling some of the best & freshest food and wine in all of Australia.
• Stroll through the lovely grounds of Cataract Gorge in Launceston.
• Fully guided tour at the unique Marakoopa show Caves, including viewing some of the best Glow Worms in Australia.
• A lovely walk under the forest canopy to the delightful Nelson Falls.
• Majestic Cradle Mountain and its stunning highland scenery.
• Panoramic views above Queenstown from the Iron Blow lookout.
• Stand on the jetty at the acclaimed Lake St Clair
• The Wall in the Wilderness art Gallery in Derwent Bridge.
• Tasmania’s most photographed waterfall - the 3 tiered Russell Falls.

Inclusions:
• 4 nights accomodation at 3.5 to 4 star lodgings.
• 4 x breakfasts and 3 x lunches provided
• 1 x evening meal provided.
• All attractions, entry fee’s and National Parks passes provided.
• The only additional expenses incurred are 3 x evening meals & and any spending money.

dayInfo.description: Arrival in Launceston - Travel into Launceston city at your leisure. Your accommodation for tonight is booked and waiting at the Best Western Plus Hotel - centrally located and walking distance to the cities restaurant and shopping areas.

Launceston to Cradle Mountain - Today we will spend the morning exploring downtown Launceston - Australia’s 3rd oldest city behind Sydney & Hobart. We will see the King Bridge, City Park, inside the beautiful old Heritage listed Post Office and of course take a 40 minute stroll through a jewel in the city - Cataract Gorge Reserve. Soon after we head westward into the Meander Valley which is an absolutely stunning farming and pastural area. Try local made ice-cream and honey tastings of more than 50 flavours at the renowned Melita Honey Farm in Chudleigh before learning about Tasmania’s oldest and biggest Leatherwood Honey producer R. Stephens Honey in Mole Creek. Our lunch stop today is a true gem hidden in the forest at 41o Degrees South Salmon Farm. After lunch a truely unique attraction follows with a guided tour of the Marakoopa Caves, exhibiting limestone & crystal formations millions of years old, along with a completely natural population of resident glow worms! From here we will snake our way up onto the central highlands plateau to Cradle Mountain National Park.

Cradle Mountain to Queenstown - Start the day with a full buffet hot and cold banquet breakfast at Cradle Mountain Hotel. Inside the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park - a photographers paradise - drive to the gorgeous Dove Lake for breathtaking views of Cradle Mountain. Take a short walk to glacier rock and then on to the appropriately named Enchanted Walk to see beautiful cascades and the Pencil Pine waterfall. Visit the old “Waldheim Cottage” of pioneer Gustav Weindorfer who made Cradle Mountain world famous. En route to Strahan we pass through beautiful Lake Rosebery, old mining towns such as Zeehan and view the Southern Ocean from one of the best lookout points on the west coast - how far can you see - perhaps Argentina? This is some of the freshest air on Earth. Arriving in the historic settlement of Strahan we see the historical train station at Regatta Point, visit an old though still operational saw mill and the award winning Woodcraft Centre with beautifully designed woodworks on display. Continue on to our evenings lodgings at the infamous west coast township of Queenstown.

Queenstown to Hobart - Queenstown is an old mining town reflecting past glory and surrounded by colourful, mineral rich mountains. Start the day with panoramic views over Queenstown from the Iron Blow lookout at the top of Mt Lyell before a lovely rainforest drive right through the World Heritage Franklin-Gordon National Park. Take a stroll into possibly Tasmania’s most photogenic waterfall - Nelson Falls, the 30 minute return walk is one of the west coasts best. We then travel through picturesque valleys and mountains, pristine forests, cross wild rivers before winding our way up Mt Arrowsmith to the geographical centre of Tasmania. Button grass plains, Eucalyptus forests, majestic mountains and spectacular lakes are in every direction here. Turn at Derwent Bridge to see Lake St Clair – Australia’s deepest freshwater lake and the inception of the mighty Derwent River. Next up is a visit to one of the states premier cultural experiences - The Wall, an amazing ongoing work by artist Greg Duncan, depicting stories of Tasmanian history hand carved in Huon pine - our most famous timber.
